Identification.LongTitle: Vessel Pollution and Dangerous Chemicals Regulations

Provision.Text: Whereas the proposed Regulations set out standards that are additional or complementary to the standards set out in the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 and the Protocols of 1978 and 1997 relating to the Convention, and the Governor in Council is satisfied that those additional or complementary standards meet the objectives of the Convention and Protocols;

Therefore, His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Transport and the Minister of Natural Resources, pursuant to subsections 7(2), 35(1)a and 120(1) and (2), paragraph 182(a), section 190 and paragraphs 207(2)(a) and 244(a) of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001b, hereby makes the annexed Vessel Pollution and Dangerous Chemicals Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Canada Shipping Act, 2001.
anti-fouling system means a coating, paint, surface treatment, surface or device that is used on a vessel to control or prevent the attachment of unwanted organisms.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: Convention sur le contrôle des systèmes antisalissure

Definition.Text: Anti-fouling Systems Convention means the International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-Fouling Systems on Ships, 2001.
arctic waters has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Arctic Waters Pollution Prevention Act.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: la construction se trouve à un stade équivalent

Definition.Text: a similar stage of construction means the stage at which

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: construction identifiable with a specific vessel begins; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assembly of that vessel reaches the lesser of 50 tonnes and 1% of the estimated mass of all structural material.

Definition.Text: BCH Code means the Code for the Construction and Equipment of Ships Carrying Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk, published by the IMO.
Board means the Marine Technical Review Board established under section 26 of the Act.
Canadian pleasure craft means a pleasure craft that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is licensed under Part 10 of the Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is principally maintained or operated in Canada, is not a Canadian vessel and is not registered or licensed under the laws of another state.

Definition.Text: cargo residues means the remnants of any cargo material on board a vessel that cannot be placed in proper cargo holds (loading excess and spillage) or that remain in cargo holds or elsewhere after unloading procedures are completed (unloading residual and spillage) and includes cargo sweepings.
cargo vessel means a vessel that is not a passenger vessel or a pleasure craft.
carried in packaged form means carried in a receptacle that has a net mass not exceeding 400 kg or a capacity not exceeding 450 L.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermEn: Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: certificat d’aptitude pour un bâtiment de servitude au large

Definition.Text: Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel means a Certificate of Fitness referred to in Resolution A.673(16).
chemical tanker means a vessel that was constructed or adapted for the carriage in bulk of any dangerous chemical.
combination carrier means a vessel designed to carry oil or solid cargoes in bulk.
crude oil means any liquid hydrocarbon mixture occurring naturally in the earth, whether or not treated to render it suitable for transportation, and includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: crude oil from which distillate fractions have been removed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: crude oil to which distillate fractions have been added.

Definition.Text: crude oil tanker means an oil tanker engaged in the trade of carrying crude oil.
dangerous chemical means any liquid substance listed in chapter 17 of the IBC Code.

deadweight means the difference in tonnes between the displacement of a vessel in water of a specific gravity of 1.025 at the load waterline corresponding to the assigned summer freeboard and the lightweight of the vessel.
emission control area means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of section 110.3,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the North American Emission Control Area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the United States Caribbean Sea area described in Appendix VII to Annex VI to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of section 111,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Baltic Sea area, as defined in regulation 1.11.2 of Annex I to MARPOL,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the North Sea area, as defined in regulation 5(1)(f) of Annex V to MARPOL,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the North American Emission Control Area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the United States Caribbean Sea area described in Appendix VII to Annex VI to MARPOL.

Definition.Text: en route, in respect of a vessel, means being underway on a course that, so far as feasible for navigational purposes, will cause any discharge to be spread over as great an area as is reasonably feasible.

fishing zone has the same meaning as a fishing zone of Canada described in the Fishing Zones of Canada (Zones 1, 2 and 3) Order, the Fishing Zones of Canada (Zones 4 and 5) Order or the Fishing Zones of Canada (Zone 6) Order.
foreign pleasure craft means a pleasure craft that is not a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: à partir de la terre la plus proche

Definition.Text: from the nearest land means seaward from the baseline from which the territorial sea of the territory in question is established in accordance with international law, except that off the northeastern coast of Australia it has the same meaning as in Annexes I, II, IV and V to MARPOL.

garbage means all kinds of victual, domestic and operational waste that is generated during the normal operation of a vessel and that is likely to be disposed of continuously or periodically, and includes plastics, dunnage, lining and packing materials, galley wastes and refuse such as paper products, rags, glass, metal, bottles, crockery, incinerator ash and cargo residues. However, it does not include fresh fish, fresh fish parts, oil, oily mixtures, noxious liquid substances, liquid substances that are listed in chapter 18 of the IBC Code and categorized as OS in the Pollution Category column of that chapter, liquid substances that are provisionally assessed under regulation 6.3 of Annex II to MARPOL as falling outside category X, Y or Z, substances listed in Schedule 1, marine pollutants, sewage or sewage sludge.

gas carrier means a cargo vessel that was constructed or adapted for the carriage in bulk of any liquefied gas or other products listed in chapter 19 of the International Code for the Construction and Equipment of Ships Carrying Liquefied Gases in Bulk, published by the IMO.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermEn: Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: eaux des Grand Lacs et du fleuve Saint-Laurent

Definition.Text: Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters means the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River and their connecting waters, and the Gulf of St. Lawrence to the baseline of the territorial sea.
handling facility means any shore or sea installation that is used for the loading or unloading of oil, oily mixtures, noxious liquid substances or dangerous chemicals to or from vessels.
IBC Code means the International Code for the Construction and Equipment of Ships Carrying Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk, published by the IMO.
IMO means the International Maritime Organization.

inland waters of Canada, except in Division 4 of Part 2, means all the rivers, lakes and other navigable fresh waters within Canada, and includes the St. Lawrence River as far seaward as a straight line drawn

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from Cap-des-Rosiers to West Point, Anticosti Island; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from Anticosti Island to the north shore of the St. Lawrence River along a meridian of longitude 63°W.

Definition.Text: installed, in respect of a marine diesel engine, means that the engine is fitted on a vessel, and that the engine’s cooling or exhaust system is an integral part of the vessel or that the engine’s fuelling system is permanently affixed to the vessel.

lightweight means the displacement of a vessel in tonnes without cargo, fuel, lubricating oil, ballast water, fresh water and feed water in tanks, consumable stores, or passengers and crew and their effects.
liquid substance means a substance that is in liquid form and has a vapour pressure not exceeding 0.28 MPa absolute at a temperature of 37.8°C.
machinery spaces has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Marine Machinery Regulations.
major conversion means, in the case of a vessel referred to in Division 1, 2, 4 or 6 of Part 2, a conversion of a vessel that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: substantially alters the dimensions or carrying capacity of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: changes the type of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is intended to substantially prolong the life of the vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: alters the vessel such that it becomes subject to any provision of that Division that would not be applicable to it otherwise.

Definition.Text: marine diesel engine means any reciprocating internal combustion engine operating on liquid or dual fuel, including any booster system or compound system.

marine pollutants has the same meaning as harmful substances in regulation 1 of Annex III to MARPOL, and includes packaging that has been used for the carriage of a harmful substance unless adequate precautions have been taken to ensure that the packaging contains no residue that is harmful to the marine environment.
marine sanitation device means any equipment that is installed on a vessel and is designed to receive and treat sewage.
MARPOL means the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 and the Protocols of 1978 and 1997 relating to the Convention.
Minister means the Minister of Transport.

NLS tanker means a vessel constructed or adapted to carry a cargo of noxious liquid substances in bulk and includes an oil tanker that is certified to carry a cargo or part cargo of noxious liquid substances in bulk.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: zone de contrôle des émissions de l’Amérique du Nord

Definition.Text: North American Emission Control Area means the North American area described in Appendix VII to Annex VI to MARPOL.
NOx Technical Code means the Technical Code on Control of Emission of Nitrogen Oxides from Marine Diesel Engines, published by the IMO.

noxious liquid substance means a liquid substance, alone or in a mixture with other substances, that is listed in chapter 17 or 18 of the IBC Code and categorized as Category X, Y or Z in the Pollution Category column of the chapter in which it is listed, or is provisionally assessed under regulation 6.3 of Annex II to MARPOL as falling into Category X, Y or Z.
offshore support vessel means a vessel to which Resolution A.673(16) applies.

oil tanker means a vessel constructed or adapted primarily to carry oil in bulk in its cargo spaces and includes a combination carrier, an NLS tanker and a gas carrier that is carrying a cargo or part cargo of oil in bulk.
oily mixture means a mixture with any oil content.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: substance qui appauvrit la couche d’ozone

Definition.Text: ozone-depleting substance means a controlled substance as defined in paragraph 4 of article 1 of the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.
passenger vessel means a vessel that carries more than 12 passengers.
plastics includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: synthetic ropes, synthetic fishing nets and plastic garbage bags; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: incinerator ash that is from plastics and may contain toxic or heavy metal residues.

Definition.Text: ppm means parts per million, by volume.

residual chlorine content means the quantity of free available chlorine determined to be in effluent when it is tested in accordance with the amperometric titration method described in section 4500-Cl D of the Standard Methods.
Resolution A.673(16) means the Guidelines for the Transport and Handling of Limited Amounts of Hazardous and Noxious Liquid Substances in Bulk on Offshore Support Vessels, IMO Resolution A.673(16).
Resolution MEPC.107(49) means the Revised Guidelines and Specifications for Pollution Prevention Equipment for Machinery Space Bilges of Ships, the Annex to IMO Resolution MEPC.107(49).
Resolution MEPC.184(59) means the Annex to the 2009 Guidelines for Exhaust Gas Cleaning Systems, IMO Resolution MEPC.184(59).
Section I waters means fishing zone 1, fishing zone 2, fishing zone 3 and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of Division 1 of Part 2, any other portion of the internal waters of Canada that is not in arctic waters; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of Divisions 4, 5 and 7 of Part 2, any other portion of the internal waters of Canada that is not in a shipping safety control zone.

Definition.Text: Section II waters means waters under Canadian jurisdiction that are not in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fishing zone 1, fishing zone 2, fishing zone 3 or any other portion of the internal waters of Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: arctic waters.

Definition.Text: segregated ballast means ballast water that is introduced into a tank that is completely separated from the cargo-oil system and oil-fuel system and permanently allocated to the carriage of ballast or to the carriage of ballast and cargoes other than oil, noxious liquid substances or substances listed in Schedule 1.
sewage means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: human body wastes and wastes from other living animals;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: drainage and other wastes from toilets and other receptacles intended to receive or retain human body wastes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: drainage from medical premises such as a dispensary or a sick bay via wash basins, wash tubs and scuppers located in such premises;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: drainage from spaces containing living animals; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: other drainage or wastes when mixed with the drainage or other wastes referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d).

Definition.Text: shipboard incinerator means a shipboard facility designed for the primary purpose of incineration on board a vessel of wastes or other matter generated during the normal operation of the vessel.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: zone de contrôle de la sécurité de la navigation

Definition.Text: shipping safety control zone has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Arctic Waters Pollution Prevention Act.

sludge oil means sludge from the fuel oil or lubricating oil separators, waste lubricating oil from main or auxiliary machinery, and waste oil from bilge water separators, oil filtering equipment or drip trays.
smoke means any solid, liquid, gas or combination of them produced by the combustion of fuel, and includes particulate matter.

Standard Methods means the Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, jointly published by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Environment Federation.
transfer operation means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of Division 1 of Part 2,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the loading of oil or an oily mixture in bulk to a vessel from a handling facility or another vessel, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the unloading of oil or an oily mixture in bulk from a vessel to a handling facility or another vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of Division 2 of Part 2,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the loading of a noxious liquid substance or dangerous chemical in bulk to a vessel from a handling facility or another vessel, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the unloading of a noxious liquid substance or dangerous chemical in bulk from a vessel to a handling facility or another vessel.

Definition.Text: waters under Canadian jurisdiction means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian waters; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: waters in the exclusive economic zone of Canada.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of these Regulations, a vessel is constructed on the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which its keel is laid, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which a similar stage of construction is reached.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of these Regulations, a reference to the authorized representative of a pleasure craft that is not a Canadian vessel is to be read as a reference to the operator of the pleasure craft.
For the purposes of these Regulations, a reference to a certificate that a vessel is required to hold and keep on board is to be read as a reference to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, a certificate issued under these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, a certificate issued in English, French or Spanish by or on behalf of the government of the state whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.

Section.MarginalNote: Referenced documents — as amended from time to time

Subsection.Text: Except as otherwise indicated in these Regulations, any reference in these Regulations to a document is a reference to the document as amended from time to time.
For the purposes of these Regulations, wherever the term “Administration” appears in a document incorporated by reference into these Regulations, it means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, the government of the state whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.

Subsection.Text: In the event of an inconsistency between a definition in a document incorporated by reference into these Regulations and any other definition in these Regulations, that other definition prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.
For the purpose of interpreting a document incorporated by reference into these Regulations, “should” is to be read as “must”.

For the purposes of these Regulations, guidelines, recommendations, requirements and similar matters set out in a document referred to in a footnote to a document incorporated by reference into these Regulations are to be considered mandatory.
Except as otherwise provided, these Regulations apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vessels in waters under Canadian jurisdiction; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian vessels everywhere.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Vessels engaged in exploration or drilling
Subsection.Text: These Regulations apply in respect of vessels that are capable of engaging in the drilling for, or the production, conservation or processing of, oil or gas, except when the vessel is on location and engaged in the exploration or drilling for, or the production, conservation or processing of, oil or gas as defined in section 2 of the Canada Oil and Gas Operations Act, in an area described in paragraph 3(a) or (b) of that Act.
Sections 187 and 189 of the Act and these Regulations do not apply in respect of government vessels.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Vessels owned or operated by a foreign state
Subsection.Text: These Regulations, other than sections 5, 30, 31, 101 and 102, do not apply in respect of vessels that are owned or operated by a foreign state when they are being used only in government non-commercial service.

Section.Text: For the purposes of sections 187 and 189 of the Act, the following substances are prescribed pollutants:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: oil and any oily mixture;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: garbage; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: organotin compounds that act as biocides.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 187 of the Act and sections 7, 29, 67, 82, 95, 100 and 126, substances may be discharged, and for the purposes of subsection 109(1) and section 110.6, substances may be emitted, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge or emission is necessary for the purpose of saving lives, securing the safety of a vessel or preventing the immediate loss of a vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge or emission occurs as a result of an accident of navigation in which a vessel or its equipment is damaged, unless the accident occurs as a result of an action that is outside the ordinary practice of seafarers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is a minimal and unavoidable leakage of oil that occurs as a result of the operation of an underwater machinery component;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is an accidental loss of a synthetic fishing net and all reasonable precautions were taken to prevent the loss;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is a discharge of garbage that results from damage to a vessel or its equipment, and all reasonable precautions were taken

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: before the occurrence of the damage to prevent and minimize the discharge, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after the occurrence of the damage to minimize the discharge; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the emission involves pollution of the air and results from damage to a vessel or its equipment, and all reasonable precautions were taken

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: before the occurrence of the damage to prevent and minimize the emission, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after the occurrence of the damage to minimize the emission.

Heading.TitleText: Detection of Violations and Enforcement of MARPOL

Subsection.Text: The Minister may board a foreign vessel and take action under Article 6 of MARPOL, including inspecting the vessel for the purpose of paragraph 5 of that Article.
In the case of a foreign vessel to which MARPOL does not apply, Article 6 applies as though MARPOL applied to the vessel.

A Canadian vessel, and a person on a Canadian vessel, must not discharge oil or an oily mixture in any of the following areas except in accordance with the requirements of regulations 15 and 34 of Annex I to MARPOL or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Mediterranean Sea area, as defined in regulation 1.11.1 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Baltic Sea area, as defined in regulation 1.11.2 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Black Sea area, as defined in regulation 1.11.3 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Gulfs area, as defined in regulation 1.11.5 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the Antarctic area, as defined in regulation 1.11.7 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the North West European waters, as defined in regulation 1.11.8 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the Southern South African waters, as defined in regulation 1.11.10 of Annex I to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Arctic waters, as defined in regulation 46.2 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: A Canadian vessel, and a person on a Canadian vessel, must not discharge a noxious liquid substance in the waters south of 60°S or in arctic waters as defined in regulation 21.2 of Annex II to MARPOL, except in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge.

A Canadian vessel, and a person on a Canadian vessel, must not discharge garbage in any of the following areas that are not under Canadian jurisdiction, except in accordance with the requirements of regulation 5(2) of Annex V to MARPOL or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: special areas, as defined in regulation 1.14 of Annex V to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Arctic waters, as defined in regulation 5.2 of Annex V to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft must ensure that any equipment that is referred to in paragraph 25(2)(a), subsection 93(2), paragraph 111.2(a) or 122(1)(b) or subsection 131.1(6) and that is on the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is of a type approved by the Minister as meeting the applicable requirements of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is maintained in good working order.

Subsection.Text: A person must not operate equipment referred to in subsection (1) that no longer meets the applicable requirements.

Section.Text: On application, the Minister must issue a certificate of type approval for any equipment referred to in subsection 9(1) if the Minister determines that the equipment meets the applicable requirements of these Regulations.

On application, the Minister must approve plans and specifications with respect to a Canadian vessel or a vessel that is recorded under the Act if the matters described in the plans and specifications meet the applicable requirements of this Subdivision and Subdivision 7.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more, or of any other vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that carries oil as cargo or as fuel, must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an oil tanker, it

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements of regulations 25.1 to 25.4 of Annex I to MARPOL respecting the hypothetical outflow of oil requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements of regulations 26.2 to 26.6 of Annex I to MARPOL respecting the size limitation and arrangements of cargo tanks,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements of regulations 27, 28.1 to 28.4 and 28.6 of Annex I to MARPOL respecting subdivision and stability,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: has slop tank arrangements that meet the requirements of regulation 29 of Annex I to MARPOL,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: is fitted with pumping, piping and discharge arrangements that meet the requirements of regulations 30.1 to 30.4 of Annex I to MARPOL,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: is fitted with an oil discharge monitoring and control system that meets the requirements of regulation 31 of Annex I to MARPOL, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: is fitted with oil-water interface detectors that meet the requirements of regulation 32 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a crude oil tanker of 20 000 tonnes deadweight or more but less than 40 000 tonnes deadweight, it meets the requirements of paragraph (a) and is fitted with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: segregated ballast tanks that meet the requirements of regulations 18.2 and 18.12 to 18.15 of Annex I to MARPOL, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a crude oil washing system and associated equipment and arrangements that meet the requirements of regulation 33.2 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an oil tanker of 30 000 tonnes deadweight or more engaged in carrying oil other than crude oil as cargo, it meets the requirements of subparagraph (b)(i) or, if the tanker is of 40 000 tonnes deadweight or more, was constructed before July 31, 1995 and has not undergone a major conversion since that date, it operates with dedicated clean ballast tanks that meet the requirements of regulation 18.8 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a crude oil tanker of 40 000 tonnes deadweight or more, it is fitted with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: segregated ballast tanks that meet the requirements of regulations 18.2 and 18.12 to 18.15 of Annex I to MARPOL, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a crude oil washing system and associated equipment and arrangements that meet the requirements of regulation 33.2 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more, unless it engages only on voyages in Section I waters and is fitted with a holding tank that has a volume adequate for the retention on board of oily bilge water, it is fitted with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: oil filtering equipment, alarm arrangements and automatic stopping arrangements that meet the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if it is of less than 10 000 gross tonnage and engages on voyages in Section II waters, oil filtering equipment that meets the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel that engages only on voyages in the inland waters of Canada and is not fitted with a holding tank that has a volume adequate for the retention on board of oily mixtures from the machinery space bilges, it is fitted with oil filtering equipment that meets the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL, with a 5 ppm bilge alarm that meets the requirements of section 13 and with an automatic stopping arrangement that is substantially similar to that referred to in regulation 14.7 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: Subparagraph (1)(a)(i) does not apply in respect of an oil tanker

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for which the building contract is placed after December 31, 2006;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is constructed after June 30, 2007, in the absence of a building contract;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is delivered after January 9, 2010; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that undergoes a major conversion

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for which the building contract is placed after December 31, 2006,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for which the construction work begins after June 30, 2007, in the absence of a building contract, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: that is completed after December 31, 2009.

Subsection.Text: Subparagraph (1)(a)(ii) applies only in respect of an oil tanker referred to in regulation 26.1 of Annex I to MARPOL that is not an oil tanker delivered on or after 1 January 2010 as defined in regulation 1.28.8 of that Annex.
Subparagraphs (1)(a)(iv), (vi) and (vii) do not apply in respect of an oil tanker that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: engages exclusively in carrying cargoes of asphalt or similar oils that, through their physical properties, inhibit the effective separation of oil and water and effective monitoring of the discharge of oil; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: engages only on voyages that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are in waters under Canadian jurisdiction within 50 nautical miles from the nearest land, other than in shipping safety control zones, and are of 72 hours or less in duration, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are in shipping safety control zones.

Subsection.Text: Subparagraphs (1)(a)(vi) and (vii) do not apply in respect of an oil tanker that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction within 50 nautical miles from the nearest land or in shipping safety control zones.
Subparagraphs (1)(a)(iv) to (vii) do not apply in respect of an oil tanker that does not have mechanical means of propulsion and cannot wash or ballast its cargo tanks while en route.
Paragraphs (1)(b) to (d) apply only in respect of an oil tanker delivered after 1 June 1982 as defined in regulation 1.28.4 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Application of paragraph (1)(e) in shipping safety controls zones
Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(e), a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that engages on voyages in shipping safety control zones must be fitted with a holding tank that has a volume adequate for the retention on board of oily bilge water. The vessel is required to meet the requirements of subparagraph (1)(e)(i) or (ii) only if the vessel also engages on voyages in Section II waters.
Paragraphs (1)(e) and (f) do not apply in respect of a vessel that does not have mechanical means of propulsion or a total auxiliary power of 400 kW or more.

For the purposes of paragraph (1)(e) and the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL in respect of oil filtering equipment, oily-water separating equipment that was installed before July 31, 1995 may be used if a process unit that meets the requirements of Appendix 1 to the Recommendation Concerning the Installation of Oily-Water Separating Equipment Under the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 as Modified by the Protocol of 1978 Relating Thereto, the Annex to IMO Resolution A.444(XI), is attached to the equipment.
The 5 ppm bilge alarm required under paragraph 12(1)(f) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of Part 2 of the Annex to Resolution MEPC.107(49);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have an oil content meter that can detect and measure 5 ppm or less of oil in a vessel’s machinery space bilge water overboard discharge;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have automatic stopping arrangements; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of section 7 of the Standard for 5 ppm Bilge Alarms for Canadian Inland Waters, TP 12301, published by Transport Canada.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs (1)(a) and (d) do not apply in respect of a 5 ppm bilge alarm installed before May 3, 2007 on a vessel constructed before January 1, 2005 if the alarm meets the applicable requirements of subparagraph 8(1)(e)(ii) of the Oil Pollution Prevention Regulations as they read on May 2, 2007.

Section.MarginalNote: Containers or enclosed deck areas for bunkering operations

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel of 100 gross tonnage or more must ensure that it is fitted with a container or has an enclosed deck area that, under even-keel conditions,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can retain oil that might leak or spill during bunkering operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a capacity of not less than 0.08 m3 if the vessel is of less than 400 gross tonnage or not less than 0.16 m3 if the vessel is of 400 gross tonnage or more; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not adversely affect the stability of the vessel or the safety of its crew.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a vessel that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is fitted with an overflow system that prevents oil from overflowing onto the open deck; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: usually fills its bunkers from a truck and is equipped with a bunkering hose that has an inside diameter of 51 mm or less and employs an automatic shut-off nozzle.

Section.MarginalNote: Containers or enclosed deck areas for oil tankers

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker must ensure that each oil cargo manifold and each cargo transfer connection point on the tanker is fitted with a container or has an enclosed deck area that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can retain oil that might leak or spill during transfer operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a means for the removal of the oil retained in it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not adversely affect the stability of the tanker or the safety of its crew.

Subsection.Text: If the largest conduit serving an oil cargo manifold or a cargo transfer connection point on an oil tanker has an inside diameter set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection, the tanker’s authorized representative must ensure that the container or enclosed deck area, under even-keel conditions, has the volume set out in column 2.

row.entry: Volume of Container or Enclosed Deck Area
51 mm or more but less than 101 mm
101 mm or more but less than 153 mm
153 mm or more but less than 305 mm

Section.MarginalNote: Tanks for oily residue and sludge oil
Section.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more must ensure that it is fitted with tanks that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have an adequate capacity, having regard to the type of machinery fitted on the vessel and the vessel’s usual length of voyage, to receive the vessel’s oily residues and sludge oil; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are designed and constructed so as to facilitate their cleaning.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that is delivered on or after 1 August 2010, as defined in regulation 1.28.9 of Annex I to MARPOL, and has an aggregate oil fuel capacity of 600 m3 or more must ensure that the requirements of regulation 12A of that Annex are met.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of an oil fuel tank that has a capacity of 30 m3 or less if the aggregate capacity of all such tanks on the vessel is 600 m3 or less.

Section.MarginalNote: Forepeak tanks and tanks forward of the collision bulkhead
Section.Text: The authorized representative and the master of a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that is put into service after February 15, 1993 must ensure that it is does not carry oil in a forepeak tank or in a tank forward of the collision bulkhead.

Section.MarginalNote: Cargo spaces in vessels other than oil tankers

Subsection.Text: If a vessel, other than an oil tanker, is fitted with cargo spaces that are constructed and used for carrying oil in bulk and have an aggregate capacity of at least 200 m3,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s authorized representative must ensure that the requirements of regulation 26.4 of Annex I to MARPOL, subparagraphs 12(1)(a)(iv) to (vii), sections 15 and 18 and Subdivision 7 are met in respect of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s master must ensure that the requirements of section 18 and subsection 40(7) are met in respect of the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel must keep on board an equipment operation manual for its oil discharge monitoring and control system that meets the requirements of regulation 31.4 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — capacity of less than 1 000 m3
Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(a), if the cargo spaces have an aggregate capacity of less than 1 000 m3 and the vessel is equipped with installations that can retain on board contaminated cargo washings and cargo wastes for the purpose of their subsequent transfer to a reception facility, the vessel’s authorized representative need not ensure that the requirements of subparagraphs 12(1)(a)(iv), (vi) and (vii) are met.

The authorized representative of a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that is fitted with main or auxiliary propulsion machinery must ensure that the vessel is equipped with one or more pumps that can transfer oily residues from its machinery space bilges and sludge oil tanks through a piping system to a reception facility.
The vessel’s authorized representative must ensure that the piping system has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a stop valve that is accessible from the weather deck; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an outlet that is accessible from the weather deck and is fitted with a standard discharge connection that meets the requirements of regulation 13 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: The vessel’s authorized representative must ensure that the piping to and from sludge oil tanks has no direct connection overboard other than the standard discharge connection.

Section.Text: The authorized representative of a Canadian vessel, or a Canadian pleasure craft, of 400 gross tonnage or more that is fitted with main or auxiliary propulsion machinery must ensure that the vessel is equipped on the weather deck with a means for stopping each pump that is used to discharge oily residues and sludge oil.

Section.MarginalNote: Retention or discharge equipment — oil tankers of 150 gross tonnage or less

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or less must ensure that it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: installations that can retain on board oily residues, contaminated cargo washings and cargo wastes for the purpose of their subsequent transfer to a reception facility; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: equipment that meets the oily mixture discharge requirements of section 30 or 31, as the case may be.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Retention or discharge equipment — vessels of less than 400 gross tonnage
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel of less than 400 gross tonnage that carries oil as fuel or as cargo must ensure that the vessel is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: installations that can retain on board oily residues for the purpose of their subsequent transfer to a reception facility; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: equipment that meets the oily mixture discharge requirements of section 30 or 31, as the case may be.

Section.MarginalNote: Issuance of Canadian Oil Pollution Prevention Certificates

Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue a Canadian Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of this Division are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Issuance of International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificates
Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue an International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of Annex I to MARPOL are met.

Section.MarginalNote: Endorsement of Canadian Oil Pollution Prevention Certificates

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a Canadian Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate must ensure that the certificate is endorsed by the Minister, within three months before or after each anniversary date of the issuance of the certificate, to indicate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Endorsement of International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificates
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds an International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by regulations 6.1.3, 6.1.4 and 7.2 of Annex I to MARPOL.

If the construction, arrangement, equipment, fittings, installations or systems of a vessel that holds a certificate issued under section 23 are changed as a result of an accident, the discovery of a defect, a repair or a major conversion that affects the requirements that were met when the certificate was issued, the authorized representative of the vessel must ensure that the Minister inspects the vessel as soon as feasible to ensure that the requirements continue to be met.
Subsection (3) does not apply in respect of minor repairs or the direct replacement of equipment or fittings that meet the requirements of the certificate.
Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more, and every other vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more, that carries oil as cargo or as fuel must hold and keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate, if the vessel is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate that is in the form set out in appendix II to Annex I to MARPOL, if the vessel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to MARPOL; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the vessel meets the applicable requirements of Annex I to MARPOL, if the vessel is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more, and every other vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that carries oil as cargo or as fuel, must keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the certificate of type approval for any of the following equipment that is fitted on the vessel:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a 100 ppm oily-water separator and a process unit,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: oil filtering equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an oil content meter for the equipment referred to in subparagraph (i) or (ii),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: an oil content meter for an oil discharge monitoring and control system, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: an oil-water interface detector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the equipment referred to in subparagraphs (a)(iii) and (iv), a calibration certificate issued by or on behalf of its manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an oil tanker, the information referred to in regulation 28.5 of Annex I to MARPOL relative to loading and distribution of cargo and the data referred to in that regulation on the ability of the tanker to comply with damage stability criteria;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an oil tanker fitted with an oil discharge monitoring and control system, an equipment operation manual that meets the requirements of regulation 31.4 of Annex I to MARPOL;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a crude oil tanker of 20 000 tonnes deadweight or more,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an Operations and Equipment Manual for the tanker’s crude oil washing system that meets the requirements of regulation 35.1 of Annex I to MARPOL and, if the tanker is a Canadian vessel, that is approved by the Minister as meeting those requirements, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: instruction manuals for the tanker’s inert gas system that contain the information and operational instructions referred to in section 11 of Inert Gas Systems, 1990 edition, published by the IMO, and, if the tanker is a Canadian vessel, that are approved by the Minister as meeting the requirements of that section; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a combination carrier in respect of which the Minister or, in the case of a combination carrier that is a foreign vessel, the government of the state whose flag the carrier is entitled to fly has allowed simple supplementary operational procedures for liquid transfer operations under regulation 27.2 of Annex I to MARPOL, procedures that meet the requirements of regulation 27.3 of that Annex.

Subsection.Text: Subparagraph (2)(e)(ii) applies

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: only in respect of an oil tanker delivered after 1 June 1982 as defined in regulation 1.28.4 of Annex I to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of Canadian vessels only in waters under Canadian jurisdiction.

Subsection.Text: Every oil tanker that is more than five years of age must keep on board the survey report file and supporting documentation, including the condition evaluation report, referred to in section 6 of the Guidelines on the Enhanced Programme of Inspections During Surveys of Bulk Carriers and Oil Tankers, Annex B to IMO Resolution A.744(18).
For the purposes of this section, the age of an oil tanker is determined from the day on which it is first delivered.
If an oil tanker engages on voyages only in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, the condition evaluation report must be in English or French.

Subject to subsections (2) and (3), every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more, and every other vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that carries oil as cargo or as fuel, must keep on board a shipboard oil pollution emergency plan that meets the requirements of regulation 37 of Annex I to MARPOL.

A vessel that does not have mechanical means of propulsion and that is fitted with internal combustion engines having a total output of less than 400 kW does not require a shipboard oil pollution emergency plan unless it is carrying 10 tonnes or more of oil

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in bulk; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in tanks, if one or more of the tanks has a capacity greater than 450 L.

Subsection.Text: If subsection 57(1) applies, the shipboard oil pollution emergency plan may be combined with the shipboard marine pollution emergency plan for noxious liquid substances, in which case the title of the plan must be the “shipboard marine pollution emergency plan”.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Damage stability and residual structural strength calculation
Subsection.Text: An oil tanker of 5 000 tonnes deadweight or more must have prompt access to computerized, shore-based damage stability and residual structural strength calculation programs.

Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more that is not alongside a wharf or quay and that is engaged with another oil tanker in a transfer operation involving oil or an oily mixture in bulk must keep on board an STS operations Plan that meets the requirements of regulation 41 of Annex I to MARPOL. In the case of a Canadian vessel, the STS operations Plan must be written in English or French or in both, according to the needs of the crew.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: transfer operations associated with fixed or floating platforms, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: drilling rigs,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: floating production, storage and off-loading facilities used for the offshore production and storage of oil, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: floating storage units used for the offshore storage of produced oil;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: bunkering operations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: transfer operations necessary for the purpose of saving lives or securing the safety of a vessel, or for combatting specific pollution incidents in order to minimize the damage from pollution.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION 4
Heading.TitleText: Discharges of Oil and Oily Mixtures

Section.Text: This Subdivision does not apply in respect of vessels in a shipping safety control zone or Canadian vessels in an area in respect of which subsection 7(1) applies.

A Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction, and a person on such a vessel, must not discharge oil or an oily mixture except in accordance with section 31 or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 187 of the Act, an oily mixture may be discharged from a vessel in Section I waters if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is en route;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: none of the oily mixture

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: originates in cargo pump room bilges, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is mixed with oil cargo residues;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is processed through oil filtering equipment that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: produces an undiluted effluent that has an oil content of not more than 15 ppm, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: triggers an alarm and a discharge-stopping device as soon as the oil content in the effluent exceeds

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: 5 ppm, if the oily mixture is discharged in the inland waters of Canada, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: 15 ppm, if the oily mixture is discharged in Section I waters that do not include the inland waters of Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge does not contain chemicals or any other substances introduced for the purpose of circumventing the detection of concentrations of oil that exceed the oil content limits specified in subparagraph (c)(iii).

Subsection.Text: The alarm required for the purposes of clause (1)(c)(iii)(A) must meet the requirements of section 13 and the alarm required for the purposes of clause (1)(c)(iii)(B) must meet the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Section.MarginalNote: Authorized discharge — Section II waters and seaward

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 187 of the Act and section 29, an oily mixture may be discharged from a vessel in Section II waters or a Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is en route;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an oil tanker, none of the oily mixture

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: originates in cargo pump room bilges, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is mixed with oil cargo residues;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is processed through oil filtering equipment that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex I to MARPOL, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: produces an undiluted effluent that has an oil content of not more than 15 ppm; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge does not contain chemicals or any other substances introduced for the purpose of circumventing the detection of concentrations of oil that exceed the oil content limit specified in subparagraph (c)(ii).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 187 of the Act and section 29, an oily mixture from cargo spaces may be discharged from a vessel in Section II waters or a Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is en route;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is more than 50 nautical miles from the nearest land;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the instantaneous rate of discharge of the oil that is in the oily mixture does not exceed 30 L per nautical mile;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the total quantity of oil discharged does not exceed

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 1/15,000 of the cargo of which the oily mixture forms part, in the case of a vessel that was put into service on or before December 31, 1979,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 1/30,000 of the cargo of which the oily mixture forms part, in the case of a vessel that is put into service after December 31, 1979, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: despite subparagraph (i), 1/30,000 of the cargo of which the oily mixture forms part, in the case of a Canadian vessel whose registration is transferred to the Register after February 15, 1993; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the oil discharge monitoring and control system is in operation and can stop the discharge of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any effluent having an oil discharge rate greater than that allowed under paragraph (c), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any oil in a quantity greater than that allowed under paragraph (d).

Subsection.Text: This Subdivision applies in respect of vessels only when they are in waters under Canadian jurisdiction.
Sections 33 and 37 and paragraphs 38(1)(b) to (d) and (f) to (j) do not apply in respect of oil tankers of less than 150 gross tonnage or other vessels of less than 400 gross tonnage.

Sections 33, 34 and 37 and paragraphs 38(1)(b) to (d) and (g) to (i) do not apply in respect of an oil tanker without a master or crew and from which oil is being unloaded if the tanker is not attended by a vessel with a master or crew and the tanker is in a location that makes it infeasible to meet the requirements of those provisions.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Application in waters that are not Canadian waters
Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 38(1)(l) also applies in respect of Canadian vessels in waters other than waters under Canadian jurisdiction; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: section 39.1 also applies in respect of Canadian vessels in the territorial sea or the exclusive economic zone of a foreign state that is a party to MARPOL.

Section.Text: If a vessel or a handling facility engages in a transfer operation, the vessel’s master and the operator of the facility must, before and during the transfer operation, have the means for two-way voice communication on a continuing basis that enables the supervisor on board the vessel and the supervisor at the facility or on board the other vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to communicate immediately as the need arises; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to direct the immediate shutdown of the transfer operation in case of an emergency.

Subsection.Text: If a vessel or a handling facility engages in a transfer operation between sunset and sunrise, the vessel’s master and the operator of the facility must ensure that illumination is provided that has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a lighting intensity of not less than 54 lx at each transfer connection point of the vessel or facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a lighting intensity of not less than 11 lx at each transfer operation work area around each transfer connection point of the vessel or facility.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), lighting intensity is to be measured on a horizontal plane 1 m above the walking surface of the facility or the working deck of the vessel, as applicable.
A person must not use a transfer conduit in a transfer operation unless the conduit

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has a bursting pressure of not less than four times its maximum design pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly marked with its maximum design pressure; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully passed, during the year before its use, a hydrostatic test to a pressure equal to one and one-half times its maximum design pressure.

Subsection.Text: If a transfer conduit used in a transfer operation is part of a vessel’s equipment, the vessel’s master must keep on board the test certificate for the hydrostatic test.
The owner of a transfer conduit that is used in a transfer operation must ensure that the conduit is used, maintained, tested and replaced in accordance with the manufacturer’s specifications.

If a transfer conduit or a connection leaks during a transfer operation, the supervisor on board the vessel and the supervisor at the handling facility or on board the other vessel must, as soon as feasible, slow down or stop the operation to remove the pressure from the conduit or connection.

Section.Text: The owner of a reception facility that receives oily residues from a vessel’s machinery space bilges or sludge oil tanks must equip the reception facility with a piping system that, at its vessel side end, is fitted with a standard discharge connection that meets the requirements of regulation 13 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Section.MarginalNote: Overall advisory control of transfers between oil tankers

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more must ensure that a transfer operation to which section 27.1 applies is under the overall advisory control of a person who meets the qualifications set out in section 6.2.1.2 of the Manual on Oil Pollution, Section I – Prevention, published by the IMO.
The person must carry out the duties set out in section 6.2.1.3 of the Manual.

Section.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that engages in a transfer operation must ensure that it is supervised on board the vessel by a person who is required to be part of the complement of the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel, by paragraph 207(3)(a), (b) or (c) or subparagraph 207(3)(d)(i) of the Marine Personnel Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel, by paragraph 241(a), subparagraph 241(b)(ii) or (iii) or paragraph 241(d) of the Marine Personnel Regulations.

Section.MarginalNote: Duties of supervisors of transfer operations — vessels

Subsection.Text: The supervisor of a transfer operation on board a vessel must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is secured, having regard to the weather and the tidal and current conditions, and the mooring lines are tended so that the movement of the vessel does not damage the transfer conduit or its connections;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: transfer procedures are established with the concurrence of the supervisor of the transfer operation at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be, with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the rates of flow and pressures for the transferred liquid,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reduction of rates of flow and pressures, where required to avoid an overflow of the tanks,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the time required to stop the transfer operation under normal conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the time required to shut down the transfer operation under emergency conditions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the communication signals for the transfer operation, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: stand by to start transfer,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: start transfer,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: slow down transfer,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: stand by to stop transfer,

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: stop transfer,

Clause.Label: (F)
Clause.Text: emergency stop of transfer, and

Clause.Label: (G)
Clause.Text: emergency shutdown of transfer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the supervisor of the transfer operation at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be, has reported readiness for the commencement of the transfer operation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person who is on duty on board the vessel in respect of the transfer operation is fully conversant with the communication signals, maintains watch over the vessel’s tanks to ensure that they do not overflow, and maintains continuous communication with that person’s counterpart at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manifold valves and tank valves on the vessel are not closed until the relevant pumps are stopped, if the closing of the valves would cause dangerous over-pressurization of the pumping system;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the rate of flow is reduced when the tanks are being topped off;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the supervisor of the transfer operation at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be, is given sufficient notice of the stopping of the transfer operation to permit them to take the necessary action to reduce the rate of flow or pressure in a safe and efficient manner;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the following measures are taken to prevent the discharge of oil:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: all cargo and bunker manifold connections that are not being used in the transfer operation are securely closed and fitted with blank flanges or other equivalent means of closure,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all overboard discharge valves are securely closed and marked to indicate that they are not to be opened during the transfer operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all scuppers are plugged;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a supply of peat moss or other absorbent material is readily available near every transfer conduit to facilitate the cleanup of any minor spillage of oil that may occur on the vessel or on the shore;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: all transfer conduits that are used in the transfer operation are supported to prevent the conduits and their connections from being subjected to any strain that might cause damage to them or cause the conduits to become disconnected;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: all reasonable precautions are taken to avoid the discharge of oil; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s STS operations Plan is implemented, if the vessel is of 150 gross tonnage or more and section 27.1 applies to the transfer operation.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Duties of supervisors of transfer operations — facilities
Subsection.Text: The supervisor of a transfer operation at a handling facility must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the supervisor of the transfer operation on board the vessel has reported readiness for the transfer operation to begin;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: continuous communication is maintained with the supervisor on board the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the manifold valves and the tank valves at the handling facility are not closed until the relevant pumps are stopped, if the closing of the valves would cause dangerous over-pressurization of the pumping system.

Section.Text: In the event of an emergency during a transfer operation, the master of a vessel and the operator of a handling facility engaged in the operation must take all necessary measures to rectify or minimize the emergency’s effects.

Section.MarginalNote: Notification of transfers between oil tankers

Subsection.Text: The master of an oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more must ensure that the tanker does not engage in a transfer operation to which section 27.1 applies unless, at least 48 hours before the transfer operation begins, the master gives notice in accordance with regulation 42.2 of Annex I to MARPOL to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the transfer operation is in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, a marine communications and traffic services officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the transfer operation is in the territorial sea or the exclusive economic zone of a foreign state that is a party to MARPOL, the appropriate official of the foreign state.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Information not available 48 hours before transfer
Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), information that is specified in regulation 42.2 of Annex I to MARPOL and that is not, because of exceptional circumstances, available 48 hours before the transfer operation begins, does not need to be included with the notice. The master of an oil tanker that is planning to unload oil or an oily mixture must ensure that the tanker does not engage in the transfer operation unless the information that was not available is provided at the earliest opportunity to the marine communications and traffic services officer or the appropriate official, as the case may be.

If the estimated time of arrival of an oil tanker at the location for the transfer operation changes by more than six hours, the master of the tanker must ensure that it does not engage in the transfer operation unless a revised estimated time of arrival is provided at the earliest opportunity to the marine communications and traffic services officer or the appropriate official, as the case may be.

Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more, and every other vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that carries oil as cargo or as fuel, must keep on board an Oil Record Book, Part I (Machinery Space Operations) in the form set out in appendix III to Annex I to MARPOL.
Every oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more must keep on board an Oil Record Book, Part II (Cargo/Ballast Operations) in the form set out in appendix III to Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Entries — Part I — officer in charge
Subsection.Text: The officer in charge of a machinery space operation set out in regulation 17.2 of Annex I to MARPOL that takes place on a vessel referred to in subsection (1) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operation is recorded without delay in the Oil Record Book, Part I (Machinery Space Operations); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign the recorded entry.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel referred to in subsection (1) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the circumstances of and reasons for any discharge referred to in paragraph 5(a) or (b), or any other accidental or exceptional discharge to which paragraph 5(c) does not apply, of oil or an oily mixture are recorded without delay in the Oil Record Book, Part I (Machinery Space Operations), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any failure of the oil filtering equipment is recorded without delay in the Oil Record Book, Part I (Machinery Space Operations);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each entry recorded in the Oil Record Book, Part I (Machinery Space Operations) is signed by the officer in charge of the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sign each page of the Oil Record Book, Part I (Machinery Space Operations) after the page is completed.

Subsection.Text: An entry in the Oil Record Book, Part I must be written

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in English or French, in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in English, French or Spanish, in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Entries — Part II — officer in charge
Subsection.Text: The officer in charge of a cargo/ballast operation set out in regulation 36.2 of Annex I to MARPOL that takes place on a vessel referred to in subsection (2) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operation is recorded without delay in the Oil Record Book, Part II (Cargo/Ballast Operations); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign the recorded entry.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel referred to in subsection (2) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the circumstances of and reasons for any discharge referred to in paragraph 5(a) or (b), or any other accidental or exceptional discharge, of oil or an oily mixture are recorded without delay in the Oil Record Book, Part II (Cargo/Ballast Operations), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any failure of the oil discharge monitoring and control system is recorded without delay in the Oil Record Book, Part II (Cargo/Ballast Operations);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each entry recorded in the Oil Record Book, Part II (Cargo/Ballast Operations) is signed by the officer in charge of the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sign each page of the Oil Record Book, Part II (Cargo/Ballast Operations) after the page is completed.

Subsection.Text: An entry in the Oil Record Book, Part II must be written

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in English or French, in the case of a Canadian vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in English, French or Spanish, in the case of a foreign vessel.

Subsection.Text: A vessel referred to in subsection (1) or (2) must keep the Oil Record Book, Part I and, if applicable, the Oil Record Book, Part II on board for three years after the day on which the last entry was made.
The Oil Record Book, Part I and, if applicable, the Oil Record Book, Part II may be part of the vessel’s official log book.

The master of a vessel must obtain from the owner or operator of a reception facility that receives oily residues from the vessel a receipt or certificate that sets out the type and amount of oily residues received and the date and time that they were received.
The master must keep the receipt or certificate on board for one year after the day on which it was issued.

Section.Text: If an alarm on a vessel is required under paragraph 12(1)(e) or (f) or subsection 30(2) to be fitted with a recording device to meet the specifications of Part 2 of the Annex to Resolution MEPC.107(49), the vessel must keep on board the data that those specifications require to be recorded (the date, the time, the alarm status of the alarm and the operating status of the oil filtering equipment) for 18 months after the data is recorded.

Subsection.Text: The master of an oil tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more that is required by section 27.1 to keep on board an STS operations Plan must ensure that the records required by the Plan are made.
The oil tanker must keep each record on board for three years after it is made.
This section applies in respect of an oil tanker

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for which the building contract is placed after July 5, 1993;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is constructed after January 5, 1994, in the absence of a building contract;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is first delivered after July 5, 1996; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that undergoes a major conversion

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for which the building contract is placed after July 5, 1993,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for which the construction work begins after January 5, 1994, in the absence of a building contract, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: that is completed after July 5, 1996.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker must ensure that it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the design and construction requirements of regulations 19.3 and 19.4 of Annex I to MARPOL, or of regulation 19.6 of that Annex if applicable, unless the tanker is designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements of regulation 19.5 of that Annex; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is designed and constructed to facilitate the inspection and maintenance of wing and double bottom tanks or spaces.

Subsection.Text: In this section, Category 2 oil tanker and Category 3 oil tanker have the same meaning as in regulations 20.3.2 and 20.3.3, respectively, of Annex I to MARPOL.
This section applies in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign vessel that is an oil tanker referred to in regulation 20.1.1 of Annex I to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel that is a Category 2 oil tanker or Category 3 oil tanker and that holds an International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker in respect of which section 43 applies;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker to which regulation 20.1.3 of Annex I to MARPOL applies and that, if applicable, meets the alternative requirements set out in that regulation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker that is entitled to fly the flag of the United States; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker that is engaged in the coasting trade as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Coasting Trade Act.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (5) to (7), the authorized representative of an oil tanker must ensure that it meets the requirements of subsection 43(2).

A Category 2 oil tanker, or a Category 3 oil tanker, that is a Canadian vessel fitted with double hull spaces that are not used for the carriage of oil and extend over the entire cargo tank length but do not fulfil the conditions specified in regulation 20.1.3 of Annex I to MARPOL, or fitted with only double bottoms or double sides that are not used for the carriage of oil and extend over the entire cargo tank length, may continue to operate if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it was in service on July 1, 2001;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its specifications set out in this subsection remain unchanged; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its continued operation does not go beyond the day in the year 2015 that is the anniversary of the date of its delivery or the day on which it reaches 25 years of age, whichever is the earlier day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Continued operation dependent on Condition Assessment Scheme
Subsection.Text: A Category 2 oil tanker, or Category 3 oil tanker, that is a Canadian vessel may continue to operate if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Board determines that the results of the Condition Assessment Scheme referred to in regulation 20.6 of Annex I to MARPOL indicate that the tanker is fit to continue to operate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the tanker’s continued operation does not go beyond the day in the year 2015 that is the anniversary of the date of its delivery or the day on which it reaches 25 years of age, whichever is the earlier day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Foreign vessels operating under regulation 20.5 or 20.7
Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (8), a Category 2 oil tanker, or a Category 3 oil tanker, that is a foreign vessel may operate if the government of the state whose flag the tanker is entitled to fly has allowed it to continue to operate under regulation 20.5 or 20.7 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Prohibited to enter ports or offshore terminals
Subsection.Text: A Category 2 oil tanker, or a Category 3 oil tanker, that is a foreign vessel and is continuing to operate under regulation 20.5 of Annex I to MARPOL after the anniversary in the year 2015 of the date of its delivery must not enter a port or an offshore terminal in waters under Canadian jurisdiction.
For the purposes of this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of delivery of a tanker is the day on which it is first delivered; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the age of a tanker is determined from the day on which it is first delivered.

Heading.TitleText: Oil Tankers Carrying Heavy Grade Oil as Cargo

Subsection.Text: In this section, heavy grade oil has the same meaning as in regulation 21.2 of Annex I to MARPOL.
This section applies in respect of an oil tanker of 600 tonnes deadweight or more that is carrying heavy grade oil as cargo.
This section does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker that is a Canadian vessel and engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
