Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker to which regulation 21.1.2 of Annex I to MARPOL applies and that, if applicable, meets the alternative requirements set out in that regulation.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (5) to (8), the authorized representative of an oil tanker must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if it is of 5 000 tonnes deadweight or more, it meets the requirements of subsection 43(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if it is of 600 tonnes deadweight or more but less than 5 000 tonnes deadweight, it meets the requirements of subsection 43(2) or is fitted with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: double bottom tanks or spaces that meet the requirements of regulation 19.6.1 of Annex I to MARPOL, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: wing tanks or spaces arranged in accordance with regulation 19.3.1 of Annex I to MARPOL that meet the requirement for distance, w, referred to in regulation 19.6.2 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: An oil tanker that is a Canadian vessel of 5 000 tonnes deadweight or more fitted with double hull spaces that are not used for the carriage of oil and extend over the entire cargo tank length but do not fulfil the conditions specified in regulation 21.1.2 of Annex I to MARPOL, or fitted with only double bottoms or double sides that are not used for the carriage of oil and extend over the entire cargo tank length, may continue to operate if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it was in service on December 4, 2003;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its specifications set out in this subsection remain unchanged; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its continued operation does not go beyond the day in the year 2015 that is the anniversary of the date of its delivery or the day on which it reaches 25 years of age, whichever is the earlier day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Continued operation dependent on Condition Assessment Scheme
Subsection.Text: An oil tanker that is a Canadian vessel of 5 000 tonnes deadweight or more that is carrying crude oil having a density at 15°C that is higher than 900 kg/m3 but lower than 945 kg/m3 may continue to operate if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Board determines, taking into consideration the tanker’s size, age, operational area and structural conditions, that the results of the Condition Assessment Scheme referred to in regulation 20.6 of Annex I to MARPOL indicate that it is fit to continue to operate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its continued operation does not go beyond the day in the year 2015 that is the anniversary of the date of its delivery or the day on which it reaches 25 years of age, whichever is the earlier day.

Subsection.Text: An oil tanker that is a Canadian vessel of 600 tonnes deadweight or more but less than 5 000 tonnes deadweight and that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (4)(b) may continue to operate if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Board determines, taking into consideration the tanker’s size, age, operational area and structural conditions, that it is fit to continue to operate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its continued operation does not go beyond the day on which it reaches 25 years of age.

Subsection.Text: An oil tanker that is a foreign vessel may operate if the government of the state whose flag the tanker is entitled to fly has allowed the tanker to continue to operate under regulation 21.5, 21.6.1 or 21.6.2 of Annex I to MARPOL.
For the purposes of this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of delivery of a tanker is the day on which it is first delivered; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the age of a tanker is determined from the day on which it is first delivered.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of any oil tanker in respect of which sections 43 to 45 do not apply.
This section does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker to which regulation 20.1.3 of Annex I to MARPOL applies and that, if applicable, meets the alternative requirements set out in that regulation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an oil tanker that does not have mechanical means of propulsion and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is of less than 2 000 gross tonnage,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has no cargo tanks that exceed 200 m3 capacity, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: engages only on voyages on

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the Mackenzie River,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the waters contiguous to the Mackenzie River that are not within shipping safety control zone 12, or

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the rivers, streams or lakes that feed into the Mackenzie River.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Oil tankers of less than 5 000 gross tonnage
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker of less than 5 000 gross tonnage must ensure that it has a double hull or a double containment system determined by the Minister to be as effective as a double hull for the prevention of a discharge of oil. However, this requirement does not apply before January 1, 2015.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Oil tankers of 5 000 gross tonnage or more
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an oil tanker of 5 000 gross tonnage or more must ensure that it meets the requirements of subsection 43(2).

Subsection (4) does not apply before January 1, 2015 in respect of an oil tanker that has either double sides or double bottoms that are contiguous with cargo spaces and meet the applicable design and construction requirements of regulation 19.3 or 19.4, as the case may be, of Annex I to MARPOL, and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is of less than 30 000 gross tonnage and less than 30 years of age; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is of 30 000 gross tonnage or more and less than 28 years of age.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (5), the age of an oil tanker is determined from the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which it is first delivered, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which a major conversion is completed, if the conversion is completed before July 6, 1996.

Section.Text: Despite paragraph 43(2)(a), subsection 45(3), paragraph 45(4)(b) and subsection 46(4), in the case of an oil tanker that is a Canadian vessel of less than 5 000 tonnes deadweight that does not have mechanical means of propulsion and engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction within 40 nautical miles from the nearest land, the height of its double bottom must in no location be less than the width calculated for its wing tanks in accordance with the formula in regulation 19.6.2 of Annex I to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: The Board may, in respect of Canadian vessels and Canadian pleasure craft, exercise the powers of the Administration conferred by regulations 3 and 5 of Annex I to MARPOL.

In the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, the requirements of this Division are subject to the exercise of the powers conferred by regulations 3 and 5 of Annex I to MARPOL by the government of the state whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 2
Heading.TitleText: Noxious Liquid Substances and Dangerous Chemicals

Section.Text: This Division applies in respect of foreign vessels in waters in the exclusive economic zone of Canada only in respect of pollution.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative and the master of a vessel must ensure that the vessel does not carry a liquid substance in bulk unless the substance

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is listed in chapter 17 or 18 of the IBC Code; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is provisionally assessed under regulation 6.3 of Annex II to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of oil.

Section.Text: On application, the Minister must approve plans and specifications with respect to a Canadian vessel or a vessel that is recorded under the Act if the matters described in the plans and specifications meet the applicable requirements of this Subdivision.

Section.MarginalNote: NLS tankers — Annex II to MARPOL

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an NLS tanker must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements of regulation 12 of Annex II to MARPOL relating to the pumping, piping and unloading arrangements, the location and size of underwater discharge outlets, and the slop tanks or other arrangements are met; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the tanker uses ventilation procedures referred to in regulation 13.3 of Annex II to MARPOL to remove cargo residues from a tank, the tanker has ventilation equipment that can produce an air jet that reaches the tank bottom.

Subsection.Text: Any of the following vessels that were constructed on or after July 1, 1986, or that are Canadian vessels that were constructed before that date and first registered or listed in Canada after February 15, 1993, must meet the applicable design, construction, equipment and systems requirements of the IBC Code:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vessels that carry a noxious liquid substance in bulk that is listed in chapter 17 of the IBC Code or is provisionally assessed under regulation 6.3 of Annex II to MARPOL as falling into Category X, Y or Z in the Pollution Category column of that chapter; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: chemical tankers that have means of self-propulsion.

Subsection.Text: Any of the following vessels that were constructed before July 1, 1986, other than Canadian vessels that were first registered or listed in Canada after February 15, 1993, must meet the applicable design, construction, equipment and systems requirements of the BCH Code:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vessels that carry a noxious liquid substance in bulk that is listed in chapter 17 of the IBC Code or is provisionally assessed under regulation 6.3 of Annex II to MARPOL as falling into Category X, Y or Z in the Pollution Category column of that chapter; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: chemical tankers that have means of self-propulsion.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3), a vessel converted to a chemical tanker, irrespective of the date of its construction, is considered to be a chemical tanker constructed on the date on which the conversion commenced unless the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: was constructed before July 1, 1986; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: was, when the conversion commenced, certified under the BCH Code to carry only those products identified by the Code as substances with pollution hazards only.

Subsection.Text: Offshore support vessels may meet the applicable design, construction, equipment and systems requirements of Resolution A.673(16) instead of the requirements referred to in subsection (2) or (3).

Section.MarginalNote: Containers or enclosed deck areas — NLS tankers

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of an NLS tanker must ensure that each noxious liquid substance cargo manifold and each cargo transfer connection point on the tanker is fitted with a container or has an enclosed deck area that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can retain noxious liquid substances that might leak or spill during transfer operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a means for the removal of the noxious liquid substances retained in it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not adversely affect the stability of the tanker or the safety of its crew.

Subsection.Text: If the largest conduit serving a noxious liquid substance cargo manifold or a cargo transfer connection point on an NLS tanker has an inside diameter set out in column 1 of the table to subsection 15(2), the tanker’s authorized representative must ensure that the container or enclosed deck area, under even-keel conditions, has the volume set out in column 2.
On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian Noxious Liquid Substance Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of this Division are met;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an International Pollution Prevention Certificate for the Carriage of Noxious Liquid Substances in Bulk to the vessel if the applicable requirements of Annex II to MARPOL are met;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an International Certificate of Fitness for the Carriage of Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk to the vessel if the applicable requirements of the IBC Code are met;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a Certificate of Fitness for the Carriage of Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk to the vessel if the applicable requirements of the BCH Code are met; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel to the vessel if the applicable requirements of Resolution A.673(16) are met.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must, on the basis of the applicable requirements that are met, specify on the certificates issued under subsection (1) the particular substances or products that the vessel is certified to carry.

The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a Canadian Noxious Liquid Substance Certificate must ensure that the certificate is endorsed by the Minister, within three months before or after each anniversary date of the issuance of the certificate, to indicate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate are met.

The authorized representative of a vessel that holds an International Pollution Prevention Certificate for the Carriage of Noxious Liquid Substances in Bulk must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by regulations 8.1.3, 8.1.4 and 9.2 of Annex II to MARPOL.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Endorsement of IBC Code certificates of fitness
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds an International Certificate of Fitness for the Carriage of Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by chapter 1 of the IBC Code.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Endorsement of BCH Code certificates of fitness
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a Certificate of Fitness for the Carriage of Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by chapter 1 of the BCH Code.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Endorsement of certificates of fitness for offshore support vessels
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by section 1.5.4 of Resolution A.673(16).

If the construction, arrangement, equipment, fittings, installations or systems of a vessel that holds a certificate issued under section 54 are changed as a result of an accident, the discovery of a defect, a repair or a major conversion that affects the requirements that were met when the certificate was issued, the authorized representative of the vessel must ensure that the Minister inspects the vessel as soon as feasible to ensure that the requirements continue to be met.
Subsection (6) does not apply in respect of minor repairs or the direct replacement of equipment or fittings that meet the requirements of the certificate.
Every NLS tanker and every chemical tanker must hold and keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian Noxious Liquid Substance Certificate, if the tanker is a Canadian vessel that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction and carries noxious liquid substances in bulk but not dangerous chemicals in bulk;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an International Pollution Prevention Certificate for the Carriage of Noxious Liquid Substances in Bulk that is in the form set out in appendix 3 to Annex II to MARPOL, if the tanker

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian vessel that does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction and carries noxious liquid substances in bulk but not dangerous chemicals in bulk, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to MARPOL and carries noxious liquid substances in bulk but not dangerous chemicals in bulk;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the tanker meets the applicable requirements of Annex II to MARPOL, if the tanker is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to MARPOL and carries noxious liquid substances in bulk but not dangerous chemicals in bulk;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an International Certificate of Fitness for the Carriage of Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk or a Certificate of Fitness for the Carriage of Dangerous Chemicals in Bulk that is in the form set out in the IBC Code or the BCH Code, as the case may be, if the tanker

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian vessel that carries dangerous chemicals in bulk, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to MARPOL and carries dangerous chemicals in bulk; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the tanker meets the applicable requirements of the IBC Code or the BCH Code, as the case may be, if the tanker is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to MARPOL and carries dangerous chemicals in bulk.

Subsection.Text: An offshore support vessel may hold and keep on board a Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel instead of a Certificate required by subsection (1).

Every NLS tanker must keep on board a procedures and arrangements manual that meets the requirements of regulation 14 of Annex II to MARPOL. In the case of a Canadian vessel, the expression “the requirements of this Annex” in regulation 14.2 of that Annex includes the requirements of section 67.
Every chemical tanker must keep on board the IBC Code or the BCH Code, as the case may be.

Subject to subsection (2), an NLS tanker of 150 gross tonnage or more must keep on board a shipboard marine pollution emergency plan for noxious liquid substances that meets the requirements of regulation 17.2 of Annex II to MARPOL.

If subsection 27(1) applies, the shipboard marine pollution emergency plan for noxious liquid substances may be combined with the shipboard oil pollution emergency plan, in which case the title of the plan must be the “shipboard marine pollution emergency plan”.

Section.Text: The master of an NLS tanker or chemical tanker must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permanent notices are displayed in conspicuous places on board, indicating the areas in which smoking and naked lights are prohibited;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while the tanker is in a port, the following notices are displayed near every access to the tanker, as appropriate:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: “NO NAKED LIGHTS / PAS DE FLAMMES NUES”,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: “NO SMOKING / DÉFENSE DE FUMER”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: “NO UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS / ACCÈS INTERDIT AUX PERSONNES NON AUTORISÉES”; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: while the tanker is in a port and the cargo being handled presents a health hazard, the notice “WARNING HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS / ATTENTION PRODUITS CHIMIQUES DANGEREUX” is displayed near every access to the tanker.

Section.Text: The master of an NLS tanker must ensure that the operational procedures with respect to cargo handling, tank cleaning, slops handling and cargo tank ballasting and deballasting are carried out in accordance with the tanker’s procedures and arrangements manual and with this Subdivision.

Subsection.Text: The master of a chemical tanker that was constructed on or after July 1, 1986, or that is a Canadian vessel that was constructed before that date and first registered or listed in Canada after February 15, 1993, must ensure that the operational requirements of the IBC Code are met.

The master of a chemical tanker referred to in subsection (1) must refuse any cargo mentioned in section 16.2.2 of the IBC Code if the analysis of the cargo has not been certified by its manufacturer or a marine chemist.
The master of a chemical tanker that is not referred to in subsection (1) must ensure that the operational requirements of chapter V of the BCH Code are met.

The master of an offshore support vessel that holds a Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel may ensure that the operational requirements of chapter 6 of Resolution A.673(16) are met instead of the requirements referred to in subsection (1) or (3).

Section.Text: The tank washing operations referred to in sections 63 and 64 must be carried out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the requirements of appendix 6 to Annex II to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in such a way that the effluent resulting from the washing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is transferred to a reception facility that can receive the effluent in an environmentally safe manner, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is not discharged.

Subsection.Text: If cargo stripping operations that involve a Category Y noxious liquid substance are carried out at a handling facility, the operator of the facility must ensure that it can receive the cargo at an average flow rate of 6 m3 per hour without creating back pressure of more than 100 kPa at the vessel’s manifold.
The vessel’s manifold must not be more than 3 m above the waterline at low mean tide.
A cargo hose or piping system that contains a noxious liquid substance must not be drained back into the vessel after the completion of a cargo stripping operation.
A tank from which a Category X noxious liquid substance has been unloaded must be washed before the vessel leaves the port of unloading unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the tank is reloaded with the same substance or a substance that is compatible with it and the tank is neither ballasted before loading nor washed after the vessel leaves the port of unloading;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s master notifies in writing the Department of Transport Marine Safety Office nearest to the vessel that the tank will be washed at another port that has adequate reception facilities; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cargo residues are removed from the tank by a ventilation procedure.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), the tank washing operation must be carried out by washing the tank and transferring the effluent to a reception facility that can receive the effluent in an environmentally safe manner until the concentration of the substance in the effluent has fallen to 0.1% by weight, and then by continuing to transfer the remaining effluent to the facility until the tank is empty.

If it is not feasible to measure the concentration of the substance to ensure that it falls within the limit specified in subsection (2) without causing undue delay to the vessel, the tank washing operation must be carried out by washing the tank and transferring the effluent to a reception facility in accordance with subparagraph 61(b)(i).
The tank washing operation must be carried out in the presence of a marine safety inspector who endorses the appropriate entries in the vessel’s Cargo Record Book required by subsection 79(1).
The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: high-viscosity substance means a noxious liquid substance in Category X or Y with a viscosity equal to or greater than 50 mPa·s at the unloading temperature.
solidifying substance means a noxious liquid substance that at the time of unloading is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at a temperature of less than 5°C above its melting point, in the case of a substance with a melting point below 15°C; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at a temperature of less than 10°C above its melting point, in the case of a substance with a melting point of 15°C or higher.

Subsection.Text: A tank from which a Category Y or Z noxious liquid substance has been unloaded must be washed before the vessel leaves the port of unloading if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the unloaded substance is a Category Y noxious liquid substance that is a high-viscosity substance or a solidifying substance; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the unloading operation is not carried out in accordance with the vessel’s procedures and arrangements manual.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (2) does not apply if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the tank is reloaded with the same substance or a substance that is compatible with it and the tank is neither ballasted before loading nor washed after the vessel leaves the port of unloading;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s master notifies in writing the Department of Transport Marine Safety Office nearest to the vessel that the tank will be washed at another port that has adequate reception facilities; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cargo residues are removed from the tank by a ventilation procedure.

Section.Text: A ventilation procedure must not be used to remove cargo residues for the purposes of paragraph 63(1)(c) or 64(3)(c) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the noxious liquid substance that was unloaded has a vapour pressure greater than 5 kPa at 20°C; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ventilation is carried out in accordance with sections 2 and 4 of appendix 7 to Annex II to MARPOL.

Section.Text: This subdivision does not apply in respect of vessels in a shipping safety control zone or of Canadian vessels in an area in respect of which subsection 7(2) applies.

Subsection.Text: A person or vessel must not discharge a noxious liquid substance carried in bulk except

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with sections 68 to 71, in the case of a discharge from an NLS tanker in Section II waters or from a Canadian vessel that is an NLS tanker in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(a) does not apply in respect of a vessel that holds a Certificate of Fitness for an Offshore Support Vessel.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 67, ballast water that contains a Category X noxious liquid substance only because the ballast water was introduced into a tank that last contained that substance may be discharged if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the tank was washed in accordance with subsection 63(2);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is en route at a speed of at least 7 knots, if it is self-propelled, or at least 4 knots, if it is not self-propelled; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is made

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in accordance with the vessel’s procedures and arrangements manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: below the waterline through an underwater discharge outlet at a rate that does not exceed the maximum rate for which the underwater discharge outlet was designed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at a distance of at least 12 nautical miles from the nearest land, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: into waters whose depth is at least 25 m.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 67, a Category Y noxious liquid substance may be discharged if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is en route at a speed of at least 7 knots, if it is self-propelled, or at least 4 knots, if it is not self-propelled; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is made

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in accordance with the vessel’s procedures and arrangements manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: below the waterline through an underwater discharge outlet at a rate that does not exceed the maximum rate for which the underwater discharge outlet was designed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at a distance of at least 12 nautical miles from the nearest land, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: into waters whose depth is at least 25 m.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 67, a Category Z noxious liquid substance may be discharged if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is en route at a speed of at least 7 knots, if it is self-propelled, or at least 4 knots, if it is not self-propelled; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is made

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in accordance with the vessel’s procedures and arrangements manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a vessel constructed after December 31, 2006, below the waterline through an underwater discharge outlet at a rate that does not exceed the maximum rate for which the underwater discharge outlet was designed;

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at a distance of at least 12 nautical miles from the nearest land, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: into waters whose depth is at least 25 m.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 67, a Category Y or Z noxious liquid substance in ballast water that is introduced into a cargo tank that last carried the substance and has been washed to such an extent that the ballast water contains less than 1 ppm of the noxious liquid substance may be discharged without regard to the discharge rate, vessel speed and discharge outlet location if the discharge is made at a distance of at least 12 nautical miles from the nearest land and into waters whose depth is at least 25 m.
In the case of an NLS tanker constructed before July 1, 1994, the ballast water is considered to contain less than 1 ppm of the noxious liquid substance previously carried if the cargo tank

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is washed in accordance with the requirements of Part A of appendix 6 to Annex II to MARPOL and subsequently washed with a complete cycle of the cleaning machine; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is washed with a water quantity not less than that required by paragraph 20 of Part B of appendix 6 to Annex II to MARPOL, using a k factor of 1.0 in the formula set out in that paragraph.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an NLS tanker other than one referred to in subsection (2), the ballast water is considered to contain less than 1 ppm of the noxious liquid substance previously carried if the cargo tank is washed in accordance with the requirements of Part B of appendix 6 to Annex II to MARPOL.

Section.Text: This Subdivision applies in respect of vessels only when they are in waters under Canadian jurisdiction or, if a transfer operation to which this Subdivision applies does not involve a noxious liquid substance, only when they are in Canadian waters.

If a vessel or a handling facility engages in a transfer operation, the vessel’s master and the operator of the facility must, before and during the transfer operation, have the means for two-way voice communication on a continuing basis that enables the supervisor on board the vessel and the supervisor at the facility or on board the other vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to communicate immediately as the need arises; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to direct the immediate shutdown of the transfer operation in case of an emergency.

Subsection.Text: If a vessel or a handling facility engages in a transfer operation between sunset and sunrise, the vessel’s master and the operator of the facility must ensure that illumination is provided that has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a lighting intensity of not less than 54 lx at each transfer connection point of the vessel or facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a lighting intensity of not less than 11 lx at each transfer operation work area around each transfer connection point of the vessel or facility.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), lighting intensity is to be measured on a horizontal plane 1 m above the walking surface of the facility or the working deck of the vessel, as applicable.
A person must not use a transfer conduit in a transfer operation unless the conduit

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has a bursting pressure of not less than five times its maximum design pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly marked with its maximum design pressure; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully passed, during the year before its use, a hydrostatic test to a pressure equal to one and one-half times its maximum design pressure.

Subsection.Text: If a transfer conduit used in a transfer operation is part of a vessel’s equipment, the vessel’s master must keep on board the test certificate for the hydrostatic test.
The owner of a transfer conduit that is used in a transfer operation must ensure that the conduit is used, maintained, tested and replaced in accordance with the manufacturer’s specifications.

If a transfer conduit or a connection leaks during a transfer operation, the supervisor on board the vessel and the supervisor at the handling facility or on board the other vessel must, as soon as feasible, slow down or stop the operation to remove the pressure from the conduit or connection.

Section.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that engages in a transfer operation must ensure that it is supervised on board the vessel by a person who is required to be part of the complement of the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel, by paragraph 207(3)(a), (b) or (c) or subparagraph 207(3)(d)(i) of the Marine Personnel Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel, by paragraph 241(a), subparagraph 241(b)(ii) or (iii) or paragraph 241(d) of the Marine Personnel Regulations.

Section.MarginalNote: Duties of supervisors of transfer operations — vessels

Subsection.Text: The supervisor of a transfer operation on board a vessel must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is secured, having regard to the weather and the tidal and current conditions, and the mooring lines are tended so that the movement of the vessel does not damage the transfer conduit or its connections;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: transfer procedures are established with the concurrence of the supervisor of the transfer operation at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be, with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the rates of flow and pressures for the transferred liquid,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reduction of rates of flow and pressures where required to avoid an overflow of the tanks,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the time required to stop the transfer operation under normal conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the time required to shut down the transfer operation under emergency conditions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the communication signals for the transfer operation, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: stand by to start transfer,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: start transfer,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: slow down transfer,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: stand by to stop transfer,

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: stop transfer,

Clause.Label: (F)
Clause.Text: emergency stop of transfer, and

Clause.Label: (G)
Clause.Text: emergency shutdown of transfer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the supervisor of the transfer operation at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be, has reported readiness for the commencement of the transfer operation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person who is on duty on board the vessel in respect of the transfer operation is fully conversant with the communication signals, maintains watch over the vessel’s tanks to ensure that they do not overflow, and maintains continuous communication with that person’s counterpart at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manifold valves and tank valves on the vessel are not closed until the relevant pumps are stopped, if the closing of the valves would cause dangerous over-pressurization of the pumping system;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the rate of flow is reduced when the tanks are being topped off;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the supervisor of the transfer operation at the handling facility or on board the other vessel, as the case may be, is given sufficient notice of the stopping of the transfer operation to permit them to take the necessary action to reduce the rate of flow or pressure in a safe and efficient manner;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the following measures are taken to prevent the discharge of a noxious liquid substance or dangerous chemical:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: all cargo manifold connections that are not being used in the transfer operation are securely closed and fitted with blank flanges or other equivalent means of closure,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all overboard discharge valves are securely closed and marked to indicate that they are not to be opened during the transfer operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all scuppers are plugged;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a supply of absorbent material is readily available near every transfer conduit to facilitate the clean-up of any minor spillage of noxious liquid substances or dangerous chemicals that may occur on the vessel or on the shore;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: all transfer conduits that are used in the transfer operation are supported to prevent the conduits and their connections from being subjected to any strain that might cause damage to them or cause the conduits to become disconnected;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: all systems, equipment, personnel and information necessary for the safety of the transfer are in readiness before the transfer operation begins;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: towing-off wires are positioned fore and aft and are ready for use without adjustment if it is necessary to tow the vessel away;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the transfer of a flammable cargo and the gas-freeing that follows the unloading of a flammable cargo is stopped when an electrical storm is in the immediate vicinity of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: no work is carried out in the cargo tank area without the authorization of the vessel’s master;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the valves in the vent system are checked for the correct setting and the flame arresters are examined for cleanliness and proper installation;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: articulated loading booms, if used, are checked for undue strain;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the pump room ventilation is running and all precautions for that area are observed;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: a tank that is required to be kept in an inert state (a state in which the oxygen content of the tank must be below a specified level), and to maintain a small positive pressure at all times, has a supply of inert gas available to maintain its inert state during the transfer operation;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: during loading,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the tank concerned is free of flammable or toxic vapours or residues,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the free end of the loading hose is securely lashed to the inside of the tank to prevent movement,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all flanges and gaskets are suitable for the purpose, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: all tank openings, other than those that are in use, are closed; and

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: all reasonable precautions are taken to avoid the discharge of a noxious liquid substance or dangerous chemical.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Duties of supervisors of transfer operations — facilities
Subsection.Text: The supervisor of a transfer operation at a handling facility must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the supervisor of the transfer operation on board the vessel has reported readiness for the transfer operation to begin;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: continuous communication is maintained with the supervisor on board the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the manifold valves and the tank valves at the handling facility are not closed until the relevant pumps are stopped, if the closing of the valves would cause dangerous over-pressurization of the pumping system.

Section.Text: In the event of an emergency during a transfer operation, the master of a vessel and the operator of a handling facility engaged in the operation must take all necessary measures to rectify or minimize the emergency’s effects.

Section.MarginalNote: Cargo Record Books for NLS tankers

Subsection.Text: Every NLS tanker must keep on board a Cargo Record Book in the form set out in appendix 2 to Annex II to MARPOL.
The officer in charge of an operation set out in appendix 2 to Annex II to MARPOL that takes place on an NLS tanker must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operation is recorded without delay in the Cargo Record Book; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign the recorded entry.

Subsection.Text: The vessel’s master must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the circumstances of and reasons for any discharge referred to in paragraph 5(a) or (b), or any other accidental or exceptional discharge, of a noxious liquid substance carried in bulk are recorded without delay in the Cargo Record Book;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each entry recorded in the Cargo Record Book is signed by the officer in charge of the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sign each page of the Cargo Record Book after the page is completed.

Subsection.Text: An entry in the Cargo Record Book must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel, be written in English or French; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel, be written in English, French or Spanish.

Subsection.Text: The vessel must keep the Cargo Record Book on board for three years after the day on which the last entry was made.
The Cargo Record Book may be part of the vessel’s official log book.

The master of a vessel must obtain from the owner or operator of a reception facility that receives noxious liquid substance residues or mixtures from the vessel a receipt or certificate that sets out the type and amount of noxious liquid substance residues or mixtures received and the date and time that they were received.
The master must keep the receipt or certificate on board for one year after the day on which it was issued.
The Board may, in respect of Canadian vessels, exercise the powers of the Administration conferred by regulations 4 and 5 of Annex II to MARPOL.

In the case of a foreign vessel, the requirements of this Division are subject to the exercise of the powers conferred by regulations 4 and 5 of Annex II to MARPOL, section 1.4 of the IBC Code, section 1.5 of the BCH Code and section 1.4 of Resolution A.673(16) by the government of the state whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.

A person or vessel must not discharge a marine pollutant that is not carried in bulk except in accordance with subsection (2) or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge.

For the purposes of subsection (1), a leakage of a marine pollutant that is not carried in bulk and is not kept as ships’ stores may be discharged if any of the spillage schedules to The EmS Guide: Emergency Response Procedures for Ships Carrying Dangerous Goods, published by the IMO, sets out procedures in respect of the leakage and those procedures are followed.

A person or vessel must not jettison a marine pollutant that is carried in packaged form unless it is necessary to do so for the purpose of saving lives, securing the safety of a vessel or preventing the immediate loss of a vessel.
This section applies in respect of pleasure craft that are not Canadian vessels only when they are in Canadian waters.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: zone désignée pour les eaux usées

Definition.Text: designated sewage area means an area set out in Schedule 2.
holding tank means a tank that is used solely for the collection and storage of sewage or sewage sludge and includes a tank that is an integral part of a toilet.

inland waters of Canada means all the rivers, lakes and other navigable fresh waters within Canada, and includes the St. Lawrence River as far seaward as a straight line drawn from Pointe-au-Père to Orient Point.

Subsection.Text: In this section, existing vessel means a vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for which the building contract was placed before May 3, 2007;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the absence of a building contract, the keel of which was laid or that was at a similar stage of construction before May 3, 2007; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the delivery of which was before May 3, 2010.

Subsection.Text: This Division does not apply before May 3, 2012 in respect of an existing vessel that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is of less than 400 gross tonnage, is not certified to carry more than 15 persons and is engaged on an international voyage; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not engaged on an international voyage.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (2),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Subdivision 2, section 95 and paragraph 96(1)(a) apply on the coming into force of this section in respect of all vessels that are in the Great Lakes, their connecting or tributary waters, or the St. Lawrence River as far east as the lower exit of the St. Lambert Lock at Montréal, Quebec; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Subdivision 2, section 95 and paragraph 96(1)(b) apply on the coming into force of this section in respect of all vessels that are in a designated sewage area.

Section.Text: On application, the Minister must approve plans and specifications with respect to a Canadian vessel or a vessel that is recorded under the Act if the matters described in the plans and specifications meet the applicable requirements of this Subdivision.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), the authorized representative of a vessel in Section I waters or Section II waters that has a toilet must ensure that the vessel is fitted with a holding tank or a marine sanitation device that meets the requirements of section 88 or 90, as the case may be.
The vessel’s authorized representative must ensure that it is fitted with facilities for the temporary storage of sewage if the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is fitted with a marine sanitation device that meets the requirements of paragraph 90(1)(d) only; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is in a designated sewage area and is fitted with a marine sanitation device that does not meet the requirements of paragraph 90(1)(b).

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of meeting the requirement of subsection (1), a Canadian vessel or Canadian pleasure craft must not be fitted with a marine sanitation device referred to in paragraph 90(1)(d).

A vessel referred to in subsection (1) that is of less than 15 gross tonnage, is not certified to carry more than 15 persons and is not operating in the inland waters of Canada or designated sewage areas may be fitted with facilities for the temporary storage of sewage instead of meeting the requirements of subsection (1) if it is not feasible to meet those requirements and the vessel has measures in place to ensure that no discharge is made otherwise than in accordance with section 96.

Section.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that any toilet fitted on the vessel is secured in a manner that ensures its safe operation in any environmental conditions likely to be encountered.
For the purposes of subsection 86(1), a holding tank must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be constructed so that it does not compromise the integrity of the hull;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be constructed of structurally sound material that prevents the tank contents from leaking;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be constructed so that the potable water system and other systems cannot become contaminated;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be resistant to corrosion by sewage;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: have an adequate volume for the amount of sewage that could be reasonably expected to be produced on a voyage in waters where the discharge of sewage is not authorized by section 96;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be provided with a discharge connection and piping system for the removal of the tank contents at a reception facility;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: be designed so that the level of sewage in the tank can be determined without the tank being opened and without contacting or removing any of the tank contents, or be equipped with a device that allows the determination to be made;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel, other than a pleasure craft, that operates solely on the Great Lakes and their connecting waters, be equipped with an alarm that indicates when the tank is 75% full by volume; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a ventilation device that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has its outlet located on the exterior of the vessel and in a safe location away from ignition sources and areas usually occupied by people,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevents the build-up within the tank of pressure that could cause damage to the tank,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is designed to minimize clogging by the contents of the tank or by climatic conditions such as snow or ice,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: is constructed of material that cannot be corroded by sewage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: has a flame screen of non-corrosive material fitted to the vent outlet.

Subsection.Text: A person must not use a transfer conduit for the purpose of removing sewage or sewage sludge from a holding tank or a temporary means of storage on a vessel to a reception facility unless it is used, maintained and secured in a manner that minimizes risk to the marine environment from a discharge of sewage or sewage sludge.

If a transfer conduit or a connection leaks during the removal of sewage or sewage sludge from a holding tank or a temporary means of storage on a vessel to a reception facility, the vessel’s master must, as soon as feasible, ensure that the removal operation is slowed down or stopped to remove the pressure from the conduit or connection.
For the purposes of subsection 86(1), a marine sanitation device must meet

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements of regulation 9.1.1 of Annex IV to MARPOL for a sewage treatment plant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: requirements substantially similar to the requirements referred to in paragraph (a) except that the standards referred to in regulation 9.1.1 include the effluent standard set out in paragraph 96(1)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the design, construction and testing requirements of Title 33, Part 159, Subpart C of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States for a Type II marine sanitation device; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements of regulation 9.1.2 of Annex IV to MARPOL for a sewage comminuting and disinfecting system.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), a marine sanitation device that was approved as an approved device under the Great Lakes Sewage Pollution Prevention Regulations and continues to meet the requirements of those Regulations as they read on May 2, 2007 may continue to be used as a marine sanitation device.

Section.MarginalNote: Issuance of International Sewage Pollution Prevention Certificates
Section.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue an International Sewage Pollution Prevention Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of Annex IV to MARPOL are met.

Subsection.Text: If the construction, arrangement, equipment, fittings, installations or systems of a vessel that holds a certificate issued under section 91 are changed as a result of an accident, the discovery of a defect, a repair or a major conversion that affects the requirements that were met when the certificate was issued, the authorized representative of the vessel must ensure that the Minister inspects the vessel as soon as feasible to ensure that the requirements continue to be met.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of minor repairs or the direct replacement of equipment or fittings that meet the requirements of the certificate.
Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more and every vessel that is certified to carry more than 15 persons must hold and keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an International Sewage Pollution Prevention Certificate in the form set out in the appendix to Annex IV to MARPOL, if the vessel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to Annex IV to MARPOL; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the vessel meets the applicable requirements of Annex IV to MARPOL, if the vessel is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to Annex IV to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: Every vessel that is fitted with a marine sanitation device in order to meet the requirements of subsection 86(1) must keep on board a certificate of type approval

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device referred to in subsection 90(1), certifying that the device meets the applicable requirements referred to in that subsection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device referred to in subsection 90(2), certifying that the device was approved as an approved device under the Great Lakes Sewage Pollution Prevention Regulations and bearing the approval number.

Subsection.Text: Every vessel that is fitted with a marine sanitation device in order to meet the requirements of subsection 86(1) and is of 400 gross tonnage or more or certified to carry more than 15 persons must keep on board a manual that sets out the operational and maintenance procedures for the device.
Every vessel must keep on board for 12 months an English or French version of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a record of the results of any tests required by subsection 97(2); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the records required by subsection 97(4).

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION 5
Heading.TitleText: Discharges of Sewage or Sewage Sludge

Section.Text: This Subdivision does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vessels in a shipping safety control zone; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pleasure craft that are not Canadian vessels and that are in waters in the exclusive economic zone of Canada.

Section.Text: A person or vessel must not discharge sewage or sewage sludge except in accordance with section 96 or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 95, sewage may be discharged if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel in an area other than a designated sewage area, the discharge is passed through a marine sanitation device and the effluent has a fecal coliform count that is equal to or less than 250/100 mL;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel in a designated sewage area, the discharge is passed through a marine sanitation device and the effluent has a fecal coliform count that is equal to or less than 14/100 mL;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel that is in Section I waters or Section II waters, but not in the inland waters of Canada or a designated sewage area, and that is of 400 gross tonnage or more or is certified to carry more than 15 persons,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the discharge is made at a distance of at least 12 nautical miles from shore and, if it is made from a holding tank or from facilities for the temporary storage of sewage, at a moderate rate while the vessel is en route at a speed of at least 4 knots, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the sewage is comminuted and disinfected using a marine sanitation device and the discharge is made at a distance of at least 3 nautical miles from shore;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel that is in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction, other than the Antarctic area, and that is of 400 gross tonnage or more or is certified to carry more than 15 persons,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the discharge is made at a distance of at least 12 nautical miles from the nearest land and, if it is made from a holding tank or from facilities for the temporary storage of sewage, at a moderate rate while the vessel is en route at a speed of at least 4 knots, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the sewage is comminuted and disinfected using a marine sanitation device and the discharge is made at a distance of at least 3 nautical miles from the nearest land; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel that is in Section I waters or Section II waters but not in the inland waters of Canada or a designated sewage area, and that is of less than 400 gross tonnage and is not certified to carry more than 15 persons,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the sewage is comminuted and disinfected using a marine sanitation device and the discharge is made at a distance of at least 1 nautical mile from shore,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the discharge is made at a distance of at least 3 nautical miles from shore while the vessel is en route at the fastest feasible speed, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if it is not feasible to meet the requirements of subparagraph (ii) because the vessel is located in waters that are less than 6 nautical miles from shore to shore, the discharge is made while the vessel is en route at a speed of at least 4 knots or, if the discharge is not feasible at that speed, the discharge is made

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: during an ebb tide, while the vessel is en route at the fastest feasible speed and into the deepest waters that are located the farthest from shore, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: while the vessel is en route at the fastest feasible speed and into the deepest and fastest moving waters that are located the farthest from shore.

Subsection.Text: In addition to the circumstances set out in paragraphs (1)(a) and (b) and subparagraphs (1)(c)(ii), (d)(ii) and (e)(i), the sewage may be discharged only if it does not contain any visible solids and the discharge does not cause

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a film or sheen to develop on the water;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a discoloration of the water or its shorelines; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sewage sludge or an emulsion to be deposited beneath the surface of the water or on its shorelines.

Subsection.Text: In addition to the circumstances set out in subparagraphs (1)(c)(i), (d)(i) and (e)(ii) and (iii), the sewage may be discharged only if the discharge does not cause visible solids to be deposited on the shoreline.
Subparagraph (1)(e)(iii) does not apply if a reception facility that can receive the sewage in an environmentally safe manner is available to receive it.

In this section, moderate rate means a rate that on average over any 24-hour or shorter period of discharge is not greater than the maximum permissible discharge rate calculated in accordance with section 3.1 of the Annex to the Recommendation on Standards for the Rate of Discharge of Untreated Sewage from Ships, IMO Resolution MEPC.157(55), and that over any hourly period is not more than 20% greater than that rate.
The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: biochemical oxygen demand means the quantity of oxygen determined to be used in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter during a five-day period when the organic matter is tested in accordance with the method described in section 5210 B of the Standard Methods.
suspended solids means the total suspended solid matter determined to be in or on a liquid when it is tested in accordance with the method described in section 2540 D of the Standard Methods.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that discharges effluent from a marine sanitation device into Section I waters must, if the Minister determines that it is necessary to do so in order to ascertain whether the effluent meets the specifications on the device’s certificate of type approval, ensure that samples of the effluent are tested in accordance with the Standard Methods to determine each of the following that is relevant to those specifications:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the fecal coliform count of the samples;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the total suspended solids content of the samples;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the 5-day biochemical oxygen demand of the samples; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of chlorine used as a disinfectant, the total residual chlorine content of the samples.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (2) does not apply if the marine sanitation device is fitted with instrumentation that meets the requirements of subsection (4).
The instrumentation referred to in subsection (3) must indicate the performance of the device by providing an automatic continuous record while the device is in operation of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the suspended matter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the residual disinfectant content, in the case of disinfection by chlorine; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the disinfection efficiency, in the case of disinfection by any other method.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: zone de protection spéciale du lac Supérieur

Definition.Text: Lake Superior Special Protection Area means the area enclosed by rhumb lines connecting the following coordinates, beginning at the northernmost point and proceeding clockwise:

MarginalNote.DefinedTermEn: Six Fathom Scarp Mid-Lake Special Protection Area

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: zone de protection spéciale du milieu du lac Six Fathom Scarp

Definition.Text: Six Fathom Scarp Mid-Lake Special Protection Area means the area enclosed by rhumb lines connecting the following coordinates, beginning at the northernmost point and proceeding clockwise:

Section.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of vessels in a shipping safety control zone or Canadian vessels in an area in respect of which subsection 7(3) applies.

A Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction, and a person on such a vessel, must not discharge garbage except in accordance with section 101 or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 187 of the Act and section 100, garbage may be discharged from a vessel in Section II waters or a Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of dunnage, lining material or packing material that does not contain plastics and can float, the discharge is made as far as feasible from the nearest land and in any case at least 25 nautical miles from the nearest land;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (c), in the case of garbage other than plastics or garbage that is referred to in paragraph (a), the discharge is made as far as feasible from the nearest land and in any case at least 12 nautical miles from the nearest land;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of garbage that is referred to in paragraph (b) and has been passed through a comminuter or grinder such that the comminuted or ground garbage can pass through a screen with openings not greater than 25 mm, the discharge is made as far as feasible from the nearest land and in any case at least 3 nautical miles from the nearest land; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of cargo residues, the discharge is made after all reasonable efforts have been made to empty the cargo hold of the cargo residues and to reclaim any cargo residues that are on the vessel.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a vessel that is alongside or within 500 m of a fixed or floating platform located more than 12 nautical miles from the nearest land and engaged in the exploration, exploitation and associated offshore processing of seabed mineral resources unless the garbage is food wastes that have been passed through a comminuter or grinder such that the comminuted or ground food wastes can pass through a screen with openings not greater than 25 mm.
For the purposes of section 187 of the Act, subject to subsections (2) to (4), cargo residues that are garbage may be discharged

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in Lake Ontario, or in Lake Erie east of a line that runs due south from Point Pelee, if the discharge is made

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at a distance of more than 12 nautical miles from shore, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of iron ore cargo residues, at a distance of more than 5.2 nautical miles from shore;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in Lake Erie, in the dredged navigation channels running between Toledo Harbor Light and Detroit River Light, if the vessel loaded cargo from a Lake Erie port immediately after unloading iron ore, coal or salt at that port and the cargo residues are residues of the unloaded iron ore, coal or salt;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in Lake Huron, other than in the Six Fathom Scarp Mid-Lake Special Protection Area, if the discharge is made

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at a distance of more than 12 nautical miles from shore, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of iron ore cargo residues, at a distance of more than 5.2 nautical miles from shore;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in Lake Huron, other than in the Six Fathom Scarp Mid-Lake Special Protection Area, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the vessel is upbound along the Thumb of Michigan between 5.04 nautical miles northeast of entrance buoys 11 and 12 and the track line turn abeam of Harbor Beach, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the cargo residues are iron ore, coal or salt and the discharge is made at a distance of more than 2.6 nautical miles from shore;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in Lake Superior, other than the Lake Superior Special Protection Area, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the discharge is made from the vessel at a distance of more than 12 nautical miles from shore, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of iron ore cargo residues, the discharge is made from the vessel at a distance of more than 5.2 nautical miles from shore;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in Lake Ontario, Lake Erie, Lake Huron, other than in the Six Fathom Scarp Mid-Lake Special Protection Area, or Lake Superior, other than the Lake Superior Special Protection Area, or in any of the connecting and tributary waters of those lakes, if the cargo residues are limestone or other clean stone;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in the St. Lawrence River west of Les Escoumins, if the vessel is en route and the cargo residues are not cargo sweepings;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in the inland waters of Canada in the St. Lawrence River east of Les Escoumins, if the vessel is en route and the discharge is made at a distance of more than 6 nautical miles from shore; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: from a vessel in the portion of the St. Lawrence River and the Gulf of St. Lawrence that is in Section I waters but not in the inland waters of Canada, if the vessel is en route and the discharge is made at a distance of more than 12 nautical miles from shore.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), cargo residues may be discharged only if all reasonable efforts have been made to empty the cargo hold of the cargo residues and to reclaim any cargo residues that are on the vessel.

For the purposes of paragraphs (1)(g) to (i), the only cargo residues that may be discharged are alumina, bauxite, bentonite, cement, chrome ore, clay, dolomite, ferromanganese, grain, gypsum, ilmenite, iron ore, iron ore concentrate, lead ore concentrate, limestone, manganese concentrate, manganese ore, nepheline syenite, perlite, quartz, salt, sand, stone, sugar, talc, urea, vermiculite and zinc ore concentrate.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a vessel when its master or a crew member ascertains by visual observation that a marine mammal is within 0.5 nautical miles of the vessel.
In subsection (3), grain means wheat, corn, oats, rye, barley, flax, soybeans, safflower, canola, rice, pulses and other seeds, and the processed form of seeds, including seedcake and cereal meals.

Every vessel of 12 m or more in length overall must display placards that notify the crew and passengers of the garbage discharge requirements of section 187 of the Act and sections 7 and 100 to 102, as applicable.
The placards must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, be written in English or French or in both, according to the needs of the crew and the passengers; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, be written in the working language of the crew and in English, French or Spanish.

Subsection.Text: In this section, length overall, in respect of a vessel, means the distance measured from the forward end of the foremost outside surface of the hull shell to the aft end of the aftermost outside surface of the hull shell.

Section.MarginalNote: Keep on board garbage management plans

Subsection.Text: Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more or that is certified to carry 15 persons or more must keep on board a garbage management plan that meets the requirements of regulation 9(2) of Annex V to MARPOL.
Every crew member must meet the applicable requirements of the plan.
Despite subsection (1), in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, the garbage management plan must be written in English or French or in both, according to the needs of the crew.
Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more or that is certified to carry 15 persons or more must keep on board a Garbage Record Book in the form set out in the appendix to Annex V to MARPOL.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a vessel that is certified to carry 15 persons or more and engages only on voyages of one hour or less.
The officer in charge of an operation referred to in regulation 9(3) of Annex V to MARPOL that takes place on a vessel in respect of which section 105 applies must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operation is recorded without delay in the Garbage Record Book; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign the recorded entry.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel in respect of which section 105 applies must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the circumstances of and reasons for any discharge referred to in paragraph 5(a), (d) or (e), or any other accidental or exceptional discharge, is recorded without delay in the Garbage Record Book;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each entry recorded in the Garbage Record Book is signed by the officer in charge of the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sign each page of the Garbage Record Book after the page is completed.

Subsection.Text: The vessel must keep the Garbage Record Book on board for two years after the day on which the last entry was made.
An entry in the Garbage Record Book must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, be written in English or French; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, be written in English, French or Spanish.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (6), garbage must be grouped into the following categories:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: plastics (Category 1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dunnage, lining material or packing material referred to in paragraph 101(1)(a) (Category 2);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: garbage referred to in paragraph 101(1)(c), other than food wastes and incinerator ash (Category 3);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: garbage referred to in paragraph 101(1)(b), other than food wastes and incinerator ash (Category 4);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: food wastes (Category 5); and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: incinerator ash, except incinerator ash from plastics that may contain toxic or heavy-metal residues (Category 6).

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: garbage that is discharged in accordance with section 101 or 102 is listed in the Garbage Record Book under the heading for Category 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6, as the case may be; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: garbage that is transferred to a reception facility is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of plastic, is listed in the Garbage Record Book under the heading for Category 1, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any other case, is listed in the Garbage Record Book under the heading for “other”.

Subsection.Text: The Garbage Record Book may be part of the vessel’s official log book.

The master of a vessel must obtain, from the owner or operator of a reception facility that receives garbage from the vessel, a receipt or certificate that sets out the type and amount of garbage received and the date and time that it was received.
The master must keep the receipt or certificate on board for one year after the day on which it was issued.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION 1
Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Control of Emissions from Vessels

Section.Text: On application, the Minister must approve plans and specifications with respect to a Canadian vessel or a vessel that is recorded under the Act if the matters described in the plans and specifications meet the applicable requirements of this Subdivision.

Subsection.Text: A vessel must not emit and a person must not permit the emission of an ozone-depleting substance from an installation on a vessel except in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the emission.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a minimal emission of an ozone-depleting substance if the emission is associated with the recapture or recycling of an ozone-depleting substance.

The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that it is not fitted with any system, equipment — including portable fire-extinguishing units — insulation or other material that contains an ozone-depleting substance.

In the case of a vessel that is constructed before May 19, 2005, subsection (3) does not apply in respect of any system, equipment, insulation or other material that contains an ozone-depleting substance and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is fitted before that date; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the contractual delivery date of the system, equipment, insulation or other material to the vessel is before that date, is fitted at any time.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a vessel that is constructed before January 1, 2020, subsection (3) does not apply in respect of any system, equipment, insulation or other material that contains a hydrochlorofluorocarbon but no other ozone-depleting substance and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is fitted before that date; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the contractual delivery date of the system, equipment, insulation or other material to the vessel is before that date, is fitted at any time.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (3) does not apply in respect of the repair or recharge of any system, equipment, insulation or other material to which subsection (4) or (5) applies.
This section does not apply in respect of permanently sealed equipment that has no refrigerant-charging connections or potentially removable components containing ozone depleting substances.

Section.Text: Sections 110.1 to 110.3 do not apply in respect of a marine diesel engine that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: intended to be used solely for emergencies;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: intended to be used solely to power any device or equipment that is intended to be used solely for emergencies on the vessel on which the device or equipment is installed; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: installed in a lifeboat that is intended to be used solely for emergencies.

Section.MarginalNote: Tier I — power output of more than 130 kW

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of a marine diesel engine that has a power output of more than 130 kW and that is installed on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed after December 31, 1999 but before January 1, 2011 and that does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that was constructed after December 31, 1999 but before January 1, 2011;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed after May 2, 2007 but before the day on which this section comes into force and that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
