Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed before January 1, 2000 and that does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, or a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that was constructed before January 1, 2000, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: after December 31, 1999 but before January 1, 2011,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the engine replaced a marine diesel engine that is not identical to the engine, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the engine was installed as an additional engine,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after December 31, 1999, a substantial modification, as defined in section 1.3.2 of the NOx Technical Code, is made to the engine, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: after December 31, 1999, the maximum continuous rating of the engine is increased by more than 10%; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed before May 3, 2007 and that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: after May 2, 2007 but before the day on which this section comes into force,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the engine replaced a marine diesel engine that is not identical to the engine and that was installed on the vessel before May 3, 2007, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the engine was installed as an additional engine, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after May 2, 2007,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a substantial modification, as defined in section 1.3.2 of the NOx Technical Code, is made to the engine, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the maximum continuous rating of the engine is increased by more than 10%.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Tier I — power output of more than 5 000 kW
Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of a marine diesel engine that has a power output of more than 5 000 kW and a displacement of 90 L or more per cylinder, and that is installed on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed after December 31, 1989 but before May 3, 2007 and that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed after December 31, 1989 but before January 1, 2000 and that does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that was constructed after December 31, 1989 but before January 1, 2000.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 110.5 and 110.6 and, in the case of a marine diesel engine to which subsection (2) applies, regulations 13.7.1 to 13.7.3 of Annex VI to MARPOL, the authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that a marine diesel engine is not operated on the vessel if the quantity of nitrogen oxides emitted from the engine, calculated as the total weighted emission of NO2, exceeds the following limits, where n represents the rated engine speed (crankshaft revolutions per minute) of the engine:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 17.0 g/kWh, where n is less than 130 revolutions per minute;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 45.0 × n-0.2 g/kWh, where n is 130 revolutions per minute or more but less than 2,000 revolutions per minute; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 9.8 g/kWh, where n is 2,000 revolutions per minute or more.

Text.Repealed: In the case of a Canadian vessel that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, a reference in regulation 13.7.1 of Annex VI to MARPOL to the vessel’s International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate is to be read as a reference to the vessel’s Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificate.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of a marine diesel engine that has a power output of more than 130 kW and that is installed on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that is constructed after December 31, 2010, other than a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed before the day on which this section comes into force and that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel, other than a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that was constructed before the day on which this section comes into force and that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the vessel was constructed before January 1, 2011, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: after December 31, 2010,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the engine replaces a marine diesel engine that is not identical to the engine and that was installed on the vessel before January 1, 2011, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the engine is installed as an additional engine; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the vessel was constructed before the day on which this section comes into force, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on or after the day on which this section comes into force,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the engine replaces a marine diesel engine that is not identical to the engine and that was installed on the vessel before the day on which this section comes into force, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the engine is installed as an additional engine.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of a marine diesel engine to which section 110.3 applies.

Subject to sections 110.5 and 110.6, the authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that a marine diesel engine is not operated on the vessel if the quantity of nitrogen oxides emitted from the engine, calculated as the total weighted emission of NO2, exceeds the following limits, where n represents the rated engine speed (crankshaft revolutions per minute) of the engine:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 14.4 g/kWh, where n is less than 130 revolutions per minute;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 44.0 × n-0.23 g/kWh, where n is 130 revolutions per minute or more but less than 2,000 revolutions per minute; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 7.7 g/kWh, where n is 2,000 revolutions per minute or more.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of a marine diesel engine that has a power output of more than 130 kW and that is installed on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that is constructed on or after January 1, 2016; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that is constructed before January 1, 2016 if, on or after January 1, 2016,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the engine replaces a marine diesel engine that is not identical to the engine and that was installed on the vessel before January 1, 2016, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the engine is installed as an additional engine.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — marine diesel engines installed on certain vessels
Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of a marine diesel engine that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: installed on a vessel with a length less than 24 m that has been specifically designed for, and is used solely for, recreational purposes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: installed on a vessel with a combined nameplate diesel engine propulsion power of less than 750 kW, if it is not possible for the engine to meet the requirements of subsection (4) because of design or construction limitations of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: installed on a vessel after December 31, 2015 as a replacement for a marine diesel engine that is not identical to the engine, if it is not possible for the engine to meet the requirements of subsection (4); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: installed on a vessel that is entitled to fly the flag of the United States.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — vessels operating in certain waters
Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that is operating

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in arctic waters, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction and are not within an emission control area; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that is operating in arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 110.5 and 110.6, the authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that a marine diesel engine is not operated on the vessel if the quantity of nitrogen oxides emitted from the engine, calculated as the total weighted emission of NO2, exceeds the following limits, where n represents the rated engine speed (crankshaft revolutions per minute) of the engine:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 3.4 g/kWh, where n is less than 130 revolutions per minute;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 9.0 × n-0.2 g/kWh, where n is 130 revolutions per minute or more but less than 2,000 revolutions per minute; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 2.0 g/kWh, where n is 2,000 revolutions per minute or more.

Subsection.Text: If the IMO, in accordance with regulation 13.10 of Annex VI to MARPOL, sets a later date for the purposes of regulation 5.1.1 of that Annex, the references in subsection (1) to January 1, 2016 are to be read as references to that later date.

Section.Text: For the purposes of subsections 110.1(3), 110.2(3) and 110.3(4), the quantity of nitrogen oxides emitted must be determined in accordance with the NOx Technical Code.

A marine diesel engine may be operated if an exhaust gas cleaning system or any other equivalent method is used to reduce the quantity of nitrogen oxides emissions to no more than the limits specified in subsection 110.1(3), 110.2(3) or 110.3(4), as the case may be.
Nitrogen oxides may be emitted in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the emission.

Section.MarginalNote: Maximum sulphur content of fuel oil

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) to (5) and section 111.1, the authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that the sulphur content of the fuel oil used on board the vessel does not exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 3.50% by mass before January 1, 2020, in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that is operating in arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 3.50% by mass before January 1, 2020, in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that is operating in arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 3.50% by mass before January 1, 2020, in the case of a Canadian vessel that is operating in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction and that are not in an emission control area;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: 0.50% by mass after December 31, 2019, in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that is operating in arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: 0.50% by mass after December 31, 2019, in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that is operating in arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: 0.50% by mass after December 31, 2019, in the case of a Canadian vessel that is operating in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction and that are not in an emission control area;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: 1.00% by mass before January 1, 2015, in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that is operating in waters under Canadian jurisdiction other than arctic waters;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: 1.00% by mass before January 1, 2015, in the case of a Canadian vessel that is operating in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction and that are in an emission control area;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: 1.00% by mass before January 1, 2015, in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that is operating in waters under Canadian jurisdiction other than arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: 0.10% by mass after December 31, 2014, in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft that is operating in waters under Canadian jurisdiction other than arctic waters;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: 0.10% by mass after December 31, 2014, in the case of a Canadian vessel that is operating in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction and that are in an emission control area; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: 0.10% by mass after December 31, 2014, in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that is operating in waters under Canadian jurisdiction other than arctic waters or in Hudson Bay, James Bay or Ungava Bay.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Steam-powered foreign vessels and foreign pleasure craft
Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that is powered by a propulsion boiler that was not originally designed for continued operation on marine distillate fuel or natural gas, the vessel’s authorized representative must ensure that, when the vessel is operating in the North American Emission Control Area or in the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters, the sulphur content of the fuel oil used on board the vessel does not exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 3.50% by mass before January 1, 2020; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 0.50% by mass after December 31, 2019.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in respect of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is powered by a propulsion boiler that was not originally designed for continued operation on marine distillate fuel or natural gas; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: operates solely on the Great Lakes and their connecting waters.

Subsection.Text: Instead of meeting the requirements of subsection (1) or (2), the authorized representative of a vessel may ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel operates an exhaust gas cleaning system that meets the requirements of Resolution MEPC.184(59); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the emissions of sulphur oxides produced by the operation of the system do not exceed the emissions that would be produced were fuel oil with the sulphur content by mass required by that subsection used on board the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel referred to in subparagraph 122(1)(a)(ii) or (iii) must ensure that the requirements of regulation 14.6 of Annex VI to MARPOL are met if the vessel is entering or leaving an emission control area and the fuel oil used on board within the area is different from the fuel oil used on board outside the area.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Residues from exhaust gas cleaning systems
Subsection.Text: If a vessel operates an exhaust gas cleaning system that has been certified in accordance with Resolution MEPC.184(59), the vessel’s authorized representative must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any exhaust gas cleaning system residues are delivered to an onshore reception facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the washwater from the operation of the system, as well as the monitoring and recording of the washwater, meets the requirements of section 10 of the Resolution.

Subsection.Text: This section, instead of section 111, applies in respect of an authorized representative’s Canadian vessels when they are operating in the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters during the period referred to in paragraph (4)(a) or during a year referred to in subsection (4) if, before the period or year begins, the authorized representative

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notifies the Minister that the authorized representative elects to have this section apply in respect of that period or year; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provides the Minister with a report that specifies the manner in which each of the vessels will be managed for the purposes of meeting the requirements of subsection (4) or (6) for that period or year.

Subsection.Text: This section, instead of section 111, applies in respect of an authorized representative’s Canadian vessels when they are operating in the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters during the period beginning on the day on which this section comes into force and ending on December 31, 2020 if the authorized representative

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the period begins, notifies the Minister that the authorized representative elects to have this section apply in respect of that period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before the period referred to in paragraph (5)(a) and before each year referred to in column 3 of the table to subsection (5), provides the Minister with a report that specifies the manner in which each of the vessels will be managed for the purposes of meeting the requirements of subsection (5) or (6) for that period or year.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Fuel oil used in other waters under Canadian jurisdiction
Subsection.Text: In the notification, the vessels’ authorized representative may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of calculating the total amount of fuel oil used on board the vessels, elect to include the fuel oil used on board any of the vessels when they are operating in waters under Canadian jurisdiction that are not within the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of calculating the average sulphur content by mass of the total amount of fuel oil used on board the vessels, elect not to include

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 10% of the sulphur content by mass of the fuel oil used on board any of the vessels that were first delivered after December 31, 2008 but before August 1, 2012, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 20% of the sulphur content by mass of the fuel oil used on board any of the vessels that were first delivered after July 31, 2012 or on which a marine diesel engine that has a power output of more than 5 000 kW was installed after July 31, 2012.

Subsection.Text: If an election is made under subsection (1), the vessels’ authorized representative must ensure that the average sulphur content by mass of the total amount of fuel oil used on board the vessels does not exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1.30% in the period beginning on the day on which this section comes into force and ending on December 31, 2013;

Subsection.MarginalNote: Average sulphur content and cumulative average sulphur content
Subsection.Text: If an election is made under subsection (2), the vessels’ authorized representative must ensure that the average sulphur content by mass of the total amount of fuel oil used on board the vessels does not exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1.70% during the period that begins on the day on which this section comes into force and ends on December 31, 2013;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amount set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection during the year set out in column 3; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the amount set out in column 2 of the table to this subsection during the period that begins on the day on which this section comes into force and ends on December 31 of the year set out in column 3.

row.entry: Cumulative average sulphur content by mass

Subsection.Text: Instead of meeting the requirements of subsection (4) or (5), the vessels’ authorized representative may ensure that any combination of the following on one or more of the vessels results in total emissions of sulphur oxides that do not exceed the total emissions of sulphur oxides that would be produced were fuel oil with the sulphur content by mass required by that subsection used on board the vessels:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of an exhaust gas cleaning system that meets the requirements of Resolution MEPC.184(59);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use of equipment or materials or the carrying out of procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the use of fuel oil with a reduced sulphur content.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Washwater from exhaust gas cleaning systems
Subsection.Text: The vessels’ authorized representative must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any exhaust gas cleaning system residues are delivered to an onshore reception facility that is licensed by the jurisdiction where the facility is located; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if one or more of the vessels operate an exhaust gas cleaning system that has been certified in accordance with Resolution MEPC.184(59), the washwater from the operation of the system, as well as the monitoring and recording of the washwater, meets the requirement of section 10 of the Resolution.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Report — the manner in which vessels will be managed
Subsection.Text: The vessels’ authorized representative must provide the Minister with a revised report as soon as feasible if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: after a report is provided under paragraph (1)(b), the manner in which any of the vessels are managed in order to meet the requirements of subsection (4) or (6) changes; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after a report is provided under paragraph (2)(b), the manner in which any of the vessels are managed in order to meet the requirements of subsection (5) or (6) changes.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Interim report — the manner in which vessels are being managed
Subsection.Text: The vessels’ authorized representative must, during the period beginning on June 1 and ending on September 30 of any year in respect of which an election is made under subsection (1) or (2), provide the Minister with an interim report that describes how each of the vessels is being managed in order to meet the requirements of subsection (4), (5) or (6) for that year.
The vessels’ authorized representative must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if an election is made under subsection (1) in respect of a period or year, provide the Minister, on or before March 1 of the year following the period or year, with a report that describes the manner in which each of the vessels was managed in order to meet the requirements of subsection (4) or (6) for that period or year; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if an election is made under subsection (2), provide the Minister, on or before March 1 of each year starting in 2014 and ending in 2021, with a report that describes the manner in which each of the vessels was managed in order to meet the requirements of subsection (5) or (6) for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the period that begins on the day on which this section comes into force and ends on December 31, 2013, in the case of a report made in 2014, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the year before the report is made, in any other case.

Subsection.Text: The reports referred to in subsection (10) must be audited for accuracy by a person who has knowledge of the methods of conducting audits and is independent of the authorized representative.
Despite paragraph 122(1)(a), if an election is made under paragraph (1)(a) or (2)(a) in respect of a vessel, the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: must hold and keep on board a Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not required to hold and keep on board an International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate, unless the vessel operates in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction and are not within the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters.

Section.MarginalNote: Documentation if exhaust gas cleaning system is operated
Section.Text: If a vessel operates an exhaust gas cleaning system referred to in paragraph 111(4)(a) or 111.1(6)(a) or (c),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel must hold and keep on board a certificate of type approval certifying that the system meets the applicable requirements referred to in Resolution MEPC.184(59);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel must keep on board an EGC System Technical Manual “Scheme A” that meets the requirements of section 4.2.2 of Resolution MEPC.184(59) or an EGC System Technical Manual “Scheme B” that meets the requirements of section 5.6 of Resolution MEPC.184(59);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel must keep on board a SOx Emissions Compliance Plan that meets the requirements of section 9.1.1 of Resolution MEPC.184(59);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized representative must ensure that the information required by Resolution MEPC.184(59) respecting the operation, maintenance, servicing, adjustments and monitoring of the system is recorded as required by the Resolution; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel must keep on board the information referred to in paragraph (d) in the form and manner required by Resolution MEPC.184(59).

Heading.TitleText: Diesel Engines with a Displacement of Less than 30 L Per Cylinder

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft must ensure that any new diesel engine that has a displacement of 7 L or more per cylinder but less than 30 L per cylinder, and that is installed on the vessel for its propulsion, has been certified

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by the United States Environmental Protection Agency as meeting the requirements of Title 40, section 1042.101, of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States for Category 2 engines; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by the government of another state as meeting requirements for emissions of particulate matter, nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons that are equivalent to the requirements referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply before January 1, 2016.

The authorized representative of an oil tanker, an NLS tanker or a gas carrier that uses a vapour collection system for volatile organic compounds must ensure that the vessel is fitted with a vapour collection system that meets the requirements of regulation 15.5 of Annex VI to MARPOL.

Subsection (1) applies in respect of a gas carrier only if the type of loading and containment systems used by the carrier allow safe retention of non-methane volatile organic compounds on board or their safe return ashore.
The authorized representative of a crude oil tanker must ensure that a volatile organic compounds management plan that meets the requirements of regulation 15.6 of Annex VI to MARPOL is implemented.

Section.Text: A person must not incinerate any of the following substances on a vessel:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: oil cargo residues, noxious liquid substance cargo residues and marine pollutants;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: polychlorinated biphenyls;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: garbage containing more than traces of heavy metals;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: refined petroleum products containing halogen compounds;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: sewage sludge and sludge oil that are not generated on board the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: exhaust gas cleaning system residues.

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition unless in a shipboard incinerator

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a person must not incinerate a substance on a vessel unless the incineration is in a shipboard incinerator.

Sewage sludge or sludge oil generated during the normal operation of a vessel may be incinerated in the main or auxiliary power plant or the boilers on the vessel if the incineration does not take place inside ports, harbours or estuaries.
A person must not incinerate polyvinyl chlorides on a vessel unless the incineration is in a shipboard incinerator that meets the requirements of regulation 16.6.1 of Annex VI to MARPOL.
This section applies in respect of a shipboard incinerator that is installed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: after December 31, 1999

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on a Canadian vessel that does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on a foreign vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after May 2, 2007 on a Canadian vessel that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Regulation 16.6.1 of Annex VI to MARPOL
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that every shipboard incinerator installed on the vessel meets the requirements of regulation 16.6.1 of Annex VI to MARPOL.

The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that the personnel responsible for the operation of a shipboard incinerator are trained and capable of implementing the guidance provided in the manufacturer’s operating manual.
The master of a vessel must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the combustion flue gas outlet temperature of a shipboard incinerator is monitored at all times; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: waste or other matter is not fed into a continuous-feed shipboard incinerator when the temperature is below 850°C.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel on which a batch-loaded shipboard incinerator is installed must ensure that it is designed so that the temperature in the combustion chamber reaches 600°C within five minutes after start-up and stabilizes at not less than 850°C.
The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that fuel oil used on board the vessel for combustion purposes does not contain inorganic acid and meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of fuel oil derived from petroleum refining, the fuel oil must be a blend of hydrocarbons, with or without the incorporation of small amounts of additives that are intended to improve performance, and must not contain any added substance or chemical waste that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: jeopardizes the vessel’s safety,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: jeopardizes the safety or health of the vessel’s personnel,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: adversely affects the performance of the vessel’s machinery, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: contributes overall to additional air pollution; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of fuel oil derived by methods other than petroleum refining, the fuel oil must not

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: jeopardize the vessel’s safety,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: jeopardize the safety or health of the vessel’s personnel,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: adversely affect the performance of the vessel’s machinery, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: contribute overall to additional air pollution.

Subsection.Text: Subparagraphs (1)(a)(ii) and (iii) and (b)(ii) and (iii) apply in respect of foreign vessels, and pleasure craft that are not Canadian vessels, only when they are in Canadian waters.

Section.MarginalNote: Canadian vessels and Canadian pleasure craft

Subsection.Text: If a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft cannot, while voyaging in accordance with its voyage plan, obtain fuel oil that meets the requirements of this Division, its master must notify the Minister and, if its port of destination is not in Canada, the competent authority of that port.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Foreign vessels and foreign pleasure craft
Subsection.Text: If a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft whose port of destination is in Canada cannot, while voyaging in accordance with its voyage plan, obtain fuel oil that meets the requirements of this Division, its master must notify the Minister.
The notification must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s name and, if applicable, the vessel’s IMO ship identification number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s port of origin and port of destination;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: details of the attempts that were made to obtain fuel oil that meets the requirements of this Division, including the names and addresses of the fuel oil suppliers contacted, and the dates on which contact was made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the sulphur content of the fuel oil that was obtained; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the measures that will be taken to obtain, as soon as feasible, fuel oil that meets the requirements of this Division.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: bulk carrier means a vessel that is intended primarily to carry dry cargo in bulk, but does not include combination carriers.
combination carrier means a vessel designed to carry liquid or dry cargo in bulk.
container vessel means a vessel designed exclusively for the carriage of containers.
existing vessel means a vessel that is not a new vessel.
gas carrier means a cargo vessel constructed or adapted, and used, for the carriage in bulk of any liquefied gas.

general cargo vessel means a vessel with a multi-deck or single deck hull designed primarily for the carriage of general cargo, but does not include livestock carriers, barge carriers, heavy load carriers, yacht carriers or nuclear fuel carriers.
new vessel means a vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for which the building contract is placed after June 30, 2013;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is constructed after June 30, 2013, in the absence of a building contract; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is delivered 30 months or more after June 30, 2015.

Definition.Text: refrigerated cargo carrier means a vessel designed exclusively for the carriage of refrigerated cargoes in holds.
ro-ro cargo vessel means a vessel designed for the carriage of cargo transportation units.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: bâtiment de charge roulier (transporteur de véhicules)

Definition.Text: ro-ro cargo vessel (vehicle carrier) means a multi-deck ro-ro cargo vessel designed for the carriage of empty cars and trucks.
ro-ro passenger vessel means a passenger vessel with ro-ro cargo spaces.
tanker means a chemical tanker, NLS tanker or oil tanker.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (3) and (4) do not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction or in the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that has a diesel-electric propulsion, turbine propulsion or hybrid propulsion system.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that is a bulk carrier, combination carrier, container vessel, gas carrier, general cargo vessel, passenger vessel, refrigerated cargo carrier, ro-ro cargo vessel, ro-ro cargo vessel (vehicle carrier), ro-ro passenger vessel or tanker, the authorized representative of the vessel must ensure that the requirements of regulation 20 of Annex VI to MARPOL are met if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is a new vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is an existing vessel and is considered to be a newly constructed vessel for the purposes of chapter 4 of Annex VI to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that is a bulk carrier, combination carrier, container vessel, gas carrier, general cargo vessel, refrigerated cargo carrier or tanker, the authorized representative of the vessel must ensure that the requirements of regulation 21 of Annex VI to MARPOL are met if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is a new vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is an existing vessel and is considered to be a newly constructed vessel for the purposes of chapter 4 of Annex VI to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a foreign vessel, the requirements of subsections (3) and (4) are subject to the exercise of the power conferred by regulation 19.4 of Annex VI to MARPOL by the government of the state whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.
This Subdivision applies only in respect of vessels in Canadian waters within 1 nautical mile from shore.
This Subdivision does not apply in respect of vessels during the start-up or maintenance of smoke-producing systems.

For the purposes of this section and section 119, the smoke chart to be used in determining the density of black smoke is the Department of Transport Smoke Chart set out in Schedule 3 or a comparable chart on which fine black dots or lines, evenly spaced on a white ground space, are so arranged as to indicate

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: density number 1, by having approximately 20% of the space black;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: density number 2, by having approximately 40% of the space black;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: density number 3, by having approximately 60% of the space black;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: density number 4, by having approximately 80% of the space black; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: density number 5, by having approximately 100% of the space black.

Subsection.Text: The density of black smoke is to be determined by visual observation, by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holding a smoke chart at arm’s length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: viewing the smoke at approximately right angles to the line of travel of the smoke; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: matching the shade of the smoke to the shade of smoke density that it most closely resembles on the smoke chart.

Subsection.Text: When a determination of the density of black smoke is made in accordance with subsections (1) and (2), the black smoke is considered to be of the density and to have the density number indicated by the shade of smoke density that it most closely resembles on the smoke chart.
Smoke that is not black smoke is considered to be of the same density and to have the same density number as black smoke that is of approximately the same degree of opacity.
In this section, black smoke means smoke that appears black or blackish.

Subject to subsection (2), a person must not operate on a vessel a fuel-burning installation that does not utilize hand-fired boilers and that is emitting smoke of a density greater than density number 1.
A fuel-burning installation that does not utilize hand-fired boilers may emit smoke of density number 2 for an aggregate of not more than 4 minutes in any 30-minute period.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Limits of smoke emission — hand-fired boilers
Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), a person must not operate on a vessel a fuel-burning installation that utilizes hand-fired boilers and that is emitting smoke of a density greater than density number 2.
A fuel-burning installation that utilizes hand-fired boilers may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: while in the Detroit River, emit smoke of a density not greater than density number 3 for an aggregate of not more than 9 minutes in any 30-minute period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while elsewhere than in the Detroit River, emit smoke

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: of a density not greater than density number 3 for an aggregate of not more than 9 minutes in any 30-minute period, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: of a density not greater than density number 4 for an aggregate of not more than 3 minutes in any 30-minute period.

Section.MarginalNote: Issuance of Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificates

Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue a Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of this Division, other than those of section 116.2, are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Issuance of International Air Pollution Prevention Certificates
Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue an International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of chapter 3 of Annex VI to MARPOL are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Issuance of International Energy Efficiency Certificate
Subsection.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue an International Energy Efficiency Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of chapter 4 of Annex VI to MARPOL are met.

Section.MarginalNote: Endorsement of Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificates

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds a Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificate must ensure that the certificate is endorsed by the Minister, within three months before or after each anniversary date of the issuance of the certificate, to indicate that the requirements for the issuance of the certificate are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Endorsement of International Air Pollution Prevention Certificates
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel that holds an International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by regulations 5.1.3, 5.1.4 and 6.3 of Annex VI to MARPOL.

If the construction, arrangement, equipment, fittings, installations or systems of a vessel that holds a certificate issued under section 120 are changed as a result of an accident, the discovery of a defect, a repair or a major conversion that affects the requirements that were met when the certificate was issued, the authorized representative of the vessel must ensure that the Minister inspects the vessel as soon as feasible to ensure that the requirements continue to be met.
Subsection (3) does not apply in respect of minor repairs or the direct replacement of equipment or fittings that meet the requirements of the certificate.
Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: hold and keep on board

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a Canadian Air Pollution Prevention Certificate, or an International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate in the form set out in appendix I to Annex VI to MARPOL, if the vessel is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction or in the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence waters,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate in the form set out in appendix I to Annex VI to MARPOL, if the vessel

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to Annex VI to MARPOL, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the vessel meets the applicable requirements of Annex VI to MARPOL, if the vessel is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to Annex VI to MARPOL; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep on board

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the vessel has a marine diesel engine in respect of which any of sections 110.1 to 110.3 apply, an applicable certificate of type approval and a Technical File that meets the requirements of section 2.3.4 of the NOx Technical Code,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the vessel has a shipboard incinerator in respect of which section 115 applies, a certificate of type approval and an equipment operation manual that specifies how to operate the incinerator within the limits set out in paragraph 2 of appendix IV to Annex VI to MARPOL, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the vessel is referred to in subparagraph (a)(ii) or (iii), a list, in the form set out in Appendix I to Annex VI to MARPOL, of equipment that contains ozone depleting substances, other than equipment referred to in subsection 109(5).

Subsection.Text: Every crude oil tanker must keep on board the volatile organic compounds management plan referred to in subsection 112(3).
Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more must hold and keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an International Energy Efficiency Certificate in the form set out in appendix VIII to Annex VI to MARPOL, if the vessel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian vessel and does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to Annex VI to MARPOL; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the vessel meets the applicable requirements of Annex VI to MARPOL, if the vessel is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to Annex VI to MARPOL.

Subsection.Text: Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, and every Canadian vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more that engages only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, must keep on board a Ship Energy Efficiency Management Plan that meets the requirements of regulation 22 of Annex VI to MARPOL. The Plan may form part of the vessel’s Safety Management System, if the vessel has one.
Subsections (3) and (4) do not apply in respect of a vessel that is entitled to fly the flag of the United States.

Section.Text: A vessel that is fitted with a marine diesel engine in respect of which any of sections 110.1 to 110.3 apply must keep on board a record book of engine parameters and maintain it in accordance with section 6.2.2 of the NOx Technical Code.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel referred to in subparagraph 122(1)(a)(ii) or (iii) must ensure that the details of fuel oil delivered to and used on board the vessel for combustion purposes are recorded in a bunker delivery note that contains at least the information specified in appendix V to Annex VI to MARPOL.
The vessel’s master must keep the bunker delivery note on board for three years after the day on which the fuel oil was delivered on board.

The vessel’s master must ensure that the requirements of regulation 18.8.1 of Annex VI to MARPOL, respecting a representative sample of the fuel oil delivered that must accompany the bunker delivery note, are met.

Every vessel referred to in subparagraph 122(1)(a)(ii) or (iii) that has a rechargeable system containing ozone depleting substances, other than any system or equipment referred to in subsection 109(5), must maintain an Ozone Depleting Substances Record Book and keep it on board.
The vessel’s master must ensure that entries are made without delay in the Ozone Depleting Substances Record Book in respect of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the repair or maintenance of equipment containing ozone depleting substances;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the recharge, full or partial, of equipment containing ozone depleting substances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any emission of ozone depleting substances;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the transfer of ozone depleting substances to land-based reception facilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the supply of ozone depleting substances to the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The entries must include the mass of the ozone depleting substances that are involved in a recharge of equipment or that are emitted, transferred or supplied, as the case may be.
The Board may, in respect of Canadian vessels and Canadian pleasure craft, exercise the powers of the Administration conferred by regulations 3.2 and 4 of Annex VI to MARPOL.

In the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, the requirements of this Division are subject to the exercise of the powers conferred by regulations 3.2 and 4 of Annex VI to MARPOL by the government of the state whose flag the vessel is entitled to fly.

A vessel in waters under Canadian jurisdiction, and a person on such a vessel, must not discharge, except in accordance with subsection (2) or in the circumstances set out in section 5 that apply in respect of the discharge, a substance listed in Schedule 1 that is not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carried in packaged form; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: carried in a cargo container, a road vehicle, a trailer, a portable tank, a railway vehicle or a tank mounted on a chassis.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), a noxious liquid substance may be discharged from a vessel in Section II waters if the discharge is made in accordance with any of sections 68 to 71.
For the purposes of subsection (1), chlorine that is in sewage effluent may be discharged from a vessel if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the discharge is made as a result of the chlorine being used in a marine sanitation device to disinfect sewage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the vessel is in Section I waters or at a distance of less than three nautical miles from shore in Section II waters, the total residual chlorine content in the effluent is equal to or less than 0.5 mg/L.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of pleasure craft that are not Canadian vessels only when they are in Canadian waters.
The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that it does not have an anti-fouling system that contains any organotin compound that acts as a biocide.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of an organotin compound applied before January 1, 2008 that has a coating that forms a barrier preventing the compound from leaching.

Section.MarginalNote: Issuance of International Anti-fouling System Certificates
Section.Text: On application by the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft and subject to paragraphs 16(4)(b) to (d) of the Act, the Minister must issue an International Anti-fouling System Certificate to the vessel if the applicable requirements of Annex 1 to the Anti-fouling Systems Convention are met.

The authorized representative of a vessel that holds an International Anti-fouling System Certificate must ensure that the certificate is endorsed as required by regulation 1(1)(b) of Annex 4 to the Anti-fouling Systems Convention.
Every vessel of 400 gross tonnage or more must hold and keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an International Anti-fouling System Certificate in the form set out in appendix 1 to Annex 4 to the Anti-fouling Systems Convention, if the vessel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is a party to the Anti-fouling Systems Convention; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of compliance certifying that the vessel meets the applicable requirements of the Anti-fouling Systems Convention, if the vessel is entitled to fly the flag of a state that is not a party to the Anti-fouling Systems Convention.

Subsection.Text: In this section, length has the same meaning as in article 2(8) of the International Convention on Load Lines, 1966, as modified by the Protocol of 1988 relating to the Convention.

A vessel that is 24 m or more in length but of less than 400 gross tonnage and does not engage only on voyages in waters under Canadian jurisdiction must keep on board a declaration confirming that the anti-fouling system applied to the vessel meets the applicable requirements of Annex 1 to the Anti-fouling Systems Convention.
The declaration must be signed by the authorized representative, in the case of a Canadian vessel, and the owner, in the case of any other vessel.
The declaration must be in the form set out in Schedule 4. It must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Canadian vessel or a Canadian pleasure craft, be written in English or French; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign vessel or a foreign pleasure craft, be written in English, French or Spanish.

Subsection.Text: The declaration must be accompanied by appropriate documentation, such as a paint receipt or a contractor invoice, or contain an appropriate endorsement of the system applied to the vessel.
The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: greywater means drainage from sinks, laundry machines, bath tubs, shower-stalls or dishwashers. It does not include sewage, or drainage from machinery spaces or workshop areas.
new passenger vessel means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger vessel that is constructed on or after the day on which this section comes into force;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger vessel that, on or after the day on which this section comes into force, undergoes a conversion that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: substantially alters the dimensions or carrying capacity of the vessel, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is intended to substantially prolong the life of the vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that, on or after the day on which this section comes into force, is converted into a passenger vessel.

Definition.Text: release includes spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, throwing and dumping.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of vessels in waters under Canadian jurisdiction other than arctic waters.
This section does not apply in respect of a release of greywater that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is necessary for the purpose of saving lives, securing the safety of a vessel or preventing the immediate loss of a vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: occurs as a result of an accident of navigation in which a vessel or its equipment is damaged, unless the accident occurs as a result of an action that is outside the ordinary practice of seafarers.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Solids in water and sheen on water prohibited
Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that any release of greywater by or from the vessel into the water does not result in the deposit of solids in the water or leave a sheen on the water.
The authorized representative of a new passenger vessel that is carrying more than 500 passengers must ensure that any release of greywater by or from the vessel into the water

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is passed through a marine sanitation device that meets the requirements of section 90; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is made at a distance of at least three nautical miles from shore.

Subsection.Text: Every vessel that is fitted with a marine sanitation device in order to meet the requirements of paragraph (5)(a) must keep on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of type approval

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a device referred to in subsection 90(1), certifying that the device meets the applicable requirements referred to in that subsection, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a device referred to in subsection 90(2), certifying that the device was approved as an approved device under the Great Lakes Sewage Pollution Prevention Regulations and bearing the approval number; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a manual that sets out the operational and maintenance procedures for the device.

Section.MarginalNote: Vessels in waters under Canadian jurisdiction

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel in waters under Canadian jurisdiction must report any discharge or anticipated discharge from the vessel if the discharge or anticipated discharge is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prohibited by section 187 of the Act or by these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: authorized by paragraph 5(a), (b), (d) or (e).

Subsection.Text: The master of a Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction must report any discharge or anticipated discharge from the vessel of oil, a noxious liquid substance carried in bulk or a marine pollutant that is not carried in bulk if the discharge or anticipated discharge is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prohibited by section 187 of the Act or by these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: authorized by paragraph 5(a), (b), (d) or (e).

Subsection.MarginalNote: When report is to be made
Subsection.Text: The master must make the report

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as a discharge occurs or is anticipated; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as feasible after a discharge occurs or is anticipated, if the master is unable to make the report under paragraph (a) because he or she is involved in activities relating to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: saving lives,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: securing the vessel’s safety or preventing its immediate loss,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: preventing or mitigating damage to the vessel or its equipment, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: preventing or mitigating damage to the environment.

Subsection.MarginalNote: If report not made in accordance with paragraph (3)(a)
Subsection.Text: If the authorized representative of a Canadian vessel, or the owner of any other vessel, is not on board the vessel and has knowledge that a report has not been made in accordance with paragraph (3)(a), the authorized representative or owner must make the report immediately.

Every report must be made in accordance with sections 2 and 3.1 to 3.3 of the appendix to the Annex to the General Principles for Ship Reporting Systems and Ship Reporting Requirements, Including Guidelines for Reporting Incidents Involving Dangerous Goods, Harmful Substances and/or Marine Pollutants, IMO Resolution A.851(20), and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the identity of every vessel involved;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the discharge or the estimated date, time and location of the anticipated discharge;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the discharge or anticipated discharge, including the type and estimated quantity of pollutant involved; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a discharge, a description of the assistance and salvage measures employed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Vessels rendering assistance or undertaking salvage
Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel must report the particulars of any action taken in rendering assistance to or undertaking salvage of another vessel whose master is required under subsection (1) or (2) to report a discharge or an anticipated discharge.
A report required by subsection (1), (2), (4) or (6) must be made to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a marine safety inspector or a marine communications and traffic services officer, in the case of a discharge or anticipated discharge in waters under Canadian jurisdiction; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an appropriate official of the nearest coastal state, in the case of a discharge or anticipated discharge from a Canadian vessel in waters that are not waters under Canadian jurisdiction.

Subsection.Text: A person who makes a report must, whenever there is further information relating to the incident and essential for the protection of the marine environment, submit to the person to whom the report was made a supplementary report with as much of that information as possible.

Despite the requirement in the IMO Resolution referred to in subsection (5) that the languages used in reports include English where language difficulties may exist, a report made to a marine safety inspector or a marine communications and traffic services officer may be made in English or French.
The operator of an oil handling facility who is required to have an oil pollution emergency plan under paragraph 168(1)(d) of the Act must, as soon as feasible,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: report any discharge or anticipated discharge of oil to the federal emergency telephone number identified in the oil pollution emergency plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: report in writing any discharge or anticipated discharge of oil to the Department of Transport Marine Safety Office nearest to the facility.

Subsection.Text: The report must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the identity of any vessel involved;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the oil handling facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and position of the person who is responsible for implementing and coordinating the oil pollution emergency plan;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the discharge or the estimated date, time and location of the anticipated discharge;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the discharge or anticipated discharge, including the type and estimated quantity of oil involved;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the response actions to be taken;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: on-scene conditions; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any other relevant information.
